documents.description: New versions of Moodle are released approximately every six months. Moodle supports upgrading from a previous version. This policy describes how the minimum version to upgrade from is calculated.

documents.description: We generate version-specific documentation and maintain this for each supported version of Moodle.

documents.description: Unfortunately, the core team does not have the resources to help people use the open source code to build custom apps.

documents.title: Moodle App Remote Themes | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: How do Remote themes work?
documents.summary: This document explains how to create and implement remote themes for the Moodle App by configuring CSS URLs and utilizing custom CSS variables. It provides guidance on development workflows, targeting specific platforms, and overriding default Ionic framework styles.

documents.description: There are two ways to send custom Push Notifications to the Moodle app users:
documents.summary: This document explains the two primary methods for sending custom push notifications to Moodle app users via the Moodle Message API or the Airnotifier API. It outlines the differences between these methods and provides technical details on payload structures and implementation requirements.

documents.title: Moodle App Development Guide | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This document contains information that developers should know before starting to code on the Mobile App. If you are only interested in developing a site plugin, you should read the Moodle App Plugins development guide instead.
documents.summary: This document provides an introductory guide for developers on setting up the development environment, debugging, and understanding the codebase structure for the Moodle mobile application.

documents.title: Links in the Moodle App | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Pressing a link inside the app
documents.summary: This document explains how the Moodle app handles internal and external links and provides instructions on customizing link behavior using specific data attributes and link handlers.

documents.title: Moodle App Notification Links | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Push notifications will open the app when clicked, and you can customize which page is open by default.

documents.title: Debugging network requests in the Moodle App | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Introduction
documents.summary: This guide provides instructions for identifying and troubleshooting common issues within the Moodle mobile app by enabling developer debugging on both the site and the application. It outlines methods for inspecting web service requests and resolving login or data record errors using browser and mobile diagnostic tools.

documents.title: Moodle App Plugins API Reference | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Content responses
documents.summary: This document details the structure of content responses and handler configurations for Moodle mobile app plugins, including available JavaScript functions and lifecycle hooks.

documents.title: Course Formats | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: You can implement custom course formats using the CoreCourseFormatDelegate:
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and customize course formats for the Moodle mobile app using the CoreCourseFormatDelegate and JavaScript handlers.

documents.title: Course Modules | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: You can implement custom course modules using the CoreCourseModuleDelegate.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement custom course modules for the Moodle mobile app using the CoreCourseModuleDelegate, covering handler declarations, content responses, and offline functionality.

documents.title: Forms | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: In this example, we are going to see how to display a form and send the data to a Web Service when it's submitted.
documents.summary: This document explains how to display forms in the Moodle mobile app and submit data to a Web Service using various methods such as data binding and direct form attributes. It also covers advanced topics like rich text editors and handling dynamic form data structures.

documents.title: Groups Selector | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: If you have an activity that uses groups, you may want to implement a group selector to filter the rendered content. There are many ways to achieve this, and we're going to outline some of them in this example.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement a group selector for filtering activity content in a mobile application using either client-side Angular logic or server-side content reloading.

documents.title: Link Handlers | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: You can create a link handler to intercept what happens when links are clicked using the CoreContentLinksDelegate.
documents.summary: Explains how to implement and customize link handlers in the Moodle app to intercept URL clicks and define specific behaviors for plugin links.

documents.title: Prefetch Handlers | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: CoreCourseModuleDelegate handlers allow you to define a list of offline functions to prefetch a module. However, you might want to create your own prefetch handler to determine what needs to be downloaded. For example, you might need to chain Web Service calls (passing the result of a Web Service request to another), and this cannot be done using offline functions.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement custom prefetch handlers for Moodle app modules to support complex offline functionality, such as chaining web service calls and handling additional arguments.

documents.title: Question Types | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: You can implement custom question types using the CoreQuestionDelegate:
documents.summary: This document defines the PHP configuration structure required to register a custom Moodle question type within the mobile application environment.

documents.title: Self Enrolment | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Using CoreEnrolDelegate handlers you can support enrolment plugins in the app. In this example, we can see how to support a self enrol plugin. You'll need to register a handler in db/mobile.php and return the following JavaScript from the method implementation:
documents.summary: This document explains how to support enrolment plugins in the Moodle app by registering handlers in CoreEnrolDelegate and implementing specific JavaScript methods.

documents.title: Troubleshooting Moodle App Plugins Development | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Plugin changes are not picked up in the app
documents.summary: This document provides solutions for common troubleshooting issues encountered during Moodle app plugin development, specifically addressing Web Service response types and data structure limitations.

documents.title: Moodle App Plugins Development Guide | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: If you want add mobile support to your plugins, you only need to write PHP code. You can also use JavaScript for advanced functionality, but mobile plugins are written the same way as any other Moodle plugin: using PHP and Mustache templates.
documents.summary: This guide explains how to add mobile support to Moodle plugins using PHP and Mustache templates by defining configuration files and output classes. It covers basic setup, file structure, and the process for rendering custom user interfaces within the Moodle mobile app environment.

documents.title: Using the Moodle App in a browser | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Browsers are not officially supported by the application in production, but you can use a Chromium-based browser for development if you don't need any native functionality.
documents.summary: This document explains how to set up and use Chromium-based browsers for developing the Moodle App, including configuration flags and environment variables. It details the advantages and limitations of browser-based development compared to testing on native devices.

documents.title: Moodle App Docker Images | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle HQ provides a couple of Docker images that contain the Moodle App ready for use. You can search all the available versions in Docker Hub.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions on how to use Moodle's official Docker images to run and configure different versions and environments of the Moodle App.

documents.title: Troubleshooting when setting up your development environment for the Moodle App | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page contains a list of common errors that have been found and how to solve them. However, keep in mind that these may be platform-dependent and could not fix the problem in your machine, even if you are seeing the same error message.
documents.summary: This document provides troubleshooting advice and solutions for common errors encountered during the development and build process of the Moodle App.

documents.title: Setting up your development environment for the Moodle App | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The structure of this page is the following:
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for setting up the development environment for the Moodle App, covering installation requirements and procedures for running the application in a browser or on native mobile devices.

documents.title: Acceptance testing for the Moodle App | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: In order to run tests that carry out automated functionality testing for the Moodle App, you can write Acceptance tests. This can be useful if you want to test plugins that are compatible with the app, or you're contributing to the app core. Behat tests for the app work the same way as tests for Moodle core, but they are not run as part of a normal Behat execution and there are some differences that we'll go through in this page.
documents.summary: This document provides comprehensive instructions for setting up and running automated acceptance tests for the Moodle App using the Behat framework. It details environment configuration, plugin requirements, and the process for writing and executing mobile-specific test scenarios.

documents.title: Continuous Integration for the Moodle App | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Tests can be useful during development, but a good test suite really shines with CI processes in place. Running tests and other checks on a regular basis can be helpful to maintain good quality assurance, and catch regressions as early as possible.
documents.summary: This document explains the techniques and tools for running automated tests for the Moodle App within continuous integration workflows, covering both plugin and core test suites.

documents.title: Unit testing for the Moodle App | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Unit tests are written in JavaScript using Jest. If you want to create a new one, Jest is already configured and you only need to create a file ending with .test.ts within the project. If you're going to do so, remember to follow the file location conventions.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions on how to write and run unit tests using Jest, covering specialized helpers for mocking TypeScript classes, services, and Angular components.

documents.title: Moodle App Overview | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Moodle App is a mobile application that helps users make the best of their Moodle sites on handheld devices. It has some additional features like offline access, and a dedicated interface adapted to mobile. It's focused on student functionality, so you won't find all the features you have on the web for teachers and admins. You can learn more about the features available in the user documentation.
documents.summary: This document provides a technical overview of the Moodle App, explaining its architecture, core technologies like Angular and Ionic, and how it interacts with Moodle sites via web services.

documents.title: Mission | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Our Mission
documents.summary: This document outlines the core mission, vision, and foundational values of the Moodle project, focusing on its commitment to empowering educators and maintaining an open, innovative learning platform.

documents.title: Plugins adoption programme | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Plugins adoption programme is a process for making it clear that a plugin is orphaned and is looking for a new maintainer. The programme is one of the mechanisms helping to minimise the risks of relying on additional plugins. The programme helps to find new maintainers for plugins whose original authors can't work on the plugin fully any more.
documents.summary: This document outlines the procedures and rules for the Moodle Plugins adoption programme, which facilitates the transfer of abandoned or orphaned plugins to new maintainers.

documents.title: Plugin contribution checklist | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Before approaching the Moodle plugins directory and submitting your plugin (or a new plugin version), you are encouraged to go through the checklists below and fix eventual issues with your plugin. Doing so will make the reviewer of your plugin happy :-) and may have impact on how long your plugin has to spend in the approval queue before it lands smoothly.
documents.summary: Provides a comprehensive checklist and set of guidelines for developers to ensure their plugins meet the requirements for submission to the Moodle plugins directory.

documents.title: Plugin code prechecks | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: In the Moodle Plugins directory, uploaded plugins versions are automatically tested against a set of formal criteria. These tests typically do not check the actual plugin functionality, security or code correctness. They are more focused on formal aspects of the coding style. As such, they are most valuable for the plugin maintainers themselves.
documents.summary: This document describes the automated coding style prechecks for Moodle plugins, explaining the meaning of the various status labels and the criteria used for testing.

documents.title: Plugin documentation | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Plugin developers, maintainers and users are welcome to include documentation about their plugin in the English Moodle Docs. Of course it is fine to have documentation elsewhere, such as the Github wiki, however one advantage of including documentation in the English Moodle Docs is that 'Moodle Docs for this page' links in Moodle (when logged in as a teacher or admin) can lead directly to your plugin documentation (as explained in the Header and footer documentation). And, very important, it will then be very easy for translators of Moodle Docs to add translations for this information.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for plugin developers and maintainers on how to document their plugins within the official Moodle Docs wiki, including template usage and linking procedures.

documents.title: Plugin QA prechecks | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Plugin QA prechecks are for testing the functionality of plugins submitted for approval in the Moodle Plugins directory. Together with code prechecks, they are part of the plugin approval process.
documents.summary: This document explains the process and technical requirements for performing quality assurance (QA) prechecks on Moodle plugins submitted for community approval. It details the test environment setup, step-by-step review workflow, and specific criteria for evaluating plugin stability and metadata.

documents.title: Plugins guardians | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: thumb
documents.summary: This document describes the Moodle Plugins guardians program, detailing its mission to maintain software quality through peer reviews and providing instructions on how community members can participate.

documents.title: Master to main | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page tries to, briefly, show all the changes required to rename any branch from master to main in general. Aimed for the Moodle Community, to facilitate the transitions of all their awesome patches, plugins and integration, although, generic enough for anybody needing to rename any branch.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for renaming a default Git branch from master to main across various platforms and local environments. It details steps for GitHub, GitLab, and other providers, as well as necessary updates for CI/CD integrations and local repository tracking.

documents.title: Plugins directory API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Plugins directory at http://moodle.org/plugins exposes some of its features via web services layer, allowing the community to develop custom tools and integrations with other services such as GitHub Actions or Travis CI.
documents.summary: This document describes the web services API for the Moodle.org Plugins directory, covering authentication methods and functions for managing plugin releases. It explains how to programmatically retrieve a list of maintained plugins and submit new versions using specific web service calls.

documents.title: Plugins directory updates | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: 13 December 2023
documents.summary: This document details recent feature updates and user interface improvements for a plugin directory, including changes to search filters, navigation, and pagination.

documents.title: Plugins directory | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: - Plugins developed and maintained by community members are listed in the Plugins directory at moodle.org.
documents.summary: This document provides links and resources for accessing the community plugin directory, contribution guidelines, and documentation for Moodle community-developed code.

documents.title: Plugin with third party libraries | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes the correct way to include third party libraries with your plugin.
documents.summary: This document outlines the standard process and requirements for incorporating third-party libraries into Moodle plugins, including licensing checks and necessary documentation files.

documents.title: Plugin contribution | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes how to contribute your code into the Plugins directory to share it with the Moodle community.
documents.summary: This document outlines the process and requirements for contributing code to the Moodle Plugins directory, including preparation, benefits, and the official approval workflow.

documents.title: Roadmap | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Our Moodle Products roadmap is designed to provide visibility on the development priorities of the Moodle HQ Product teams portfolio, consisting of Moodle LMS, Moodle Workplace, MoodleCloud, Moodle Apps, Moodle Community Sites, Moodle Academy and Tech Transformation.
documents.summary: This document explains the purpose, creation process, and strategic priorities of the Moodle Products roadmap, outlining how community feedback and organizational goals drive software development.

documents.title: Overview | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page gives an overview of the process of developing Moodle and outlines some of the basic concepts to better understand this Developer documentation.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the Moodle development ecosystem, detailing the key contributors, release cycles, support policies, and core development standards.

documents.title: Confirmation messages | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Confirmation messages prompt people to confirm actions that have significant consequences or are difficult to undo. They can also help prevent errors or unexpected results by verifying user intent before proceeding with an action.
documents.summary: This document provides design and content guidelines for creating clear and effective confirmation messages that help users verify actions with significant consequences.

documents.title: Content principles | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Our vision
documents.summary: This document outlines the vision, goals, and principles for Moodle content design, focusing on creating simple, inclusive, and supportive user experiences.

documents.title: Empty states | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Empty states appear when there's nothing to display to our users. They can happen in a variety of situations:
documents.summary: This document provides design and content guidelines for creating effective empty states to improve user engagement and onboarding when no content is currently available in the interface.

documents.title: Error messages | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Error messages describe issues that stop users from finishing a task, or the system from functioning properly. A good error message explains what happened, the reason why it happened, and what the user can do to move forward. They may even provide a way forward in the call to action.
documents.summary: This document provides comprehensive guidelines and best practices for writing clear, actionable error messages that help users understand and resolve issues. It covers structural elements including titles, descriptions, and calls to action with specific examples of tone and language.

documents.title: Success messages | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Success messages tell users that they've completed a task or achieved a goal, or that an action within the system has been successfully completed.
documents.summary: This document provides guidelines and best practices for writing concise and effective success messages that inform users about completed tasks. It covers content structure, tone, and the appropriate use of calls to action.

documents.title: Writing for accessibility | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: What does accessibility mean?
documents.summary: This document provides practical guidelines for creating accessible user interfaces and content in Moodle, focusing on WCAG 2.2 AA compliance for links, headings, and alternative text.

documents.title: Grammar and mechanics | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Structuring content
documents.summary: This document provides stylistic and formatting guidelines for writing and structuring content, covering headings, numbers, dates, punctuation, and language conventions.

documents.title: How we write - a focus on translation | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Keep it simple
documents.summary: This document provides stylistic and linguistic guidelines for writing clear, inclusive, and easily translatable content for a global audience.

documents.title: Values, personality and principles | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Our values are the core Moodle beliefs and unify everything we do. Our personality is influenced by our values and describes the set of characteristics that we attribute to Moodle. Or, to put it another way, it's how we describe Moodle as if Moodle were a person. Understanding our brand personality is essential because it helps us connect more deeply to our brand identity and fosters brand loyalty.
documents.summary: This document defines Moodle's core brand identity by outlining its fundamental values, personality traits, and guiding principles that inform the organization's culture and behavior.

documents.title: Voice and tone | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Our voice and tone are how we express ourselves.
documents.summary: This document defines Moodle's brand voice and explains how to adapt communication tones across different audiences, contexts, and platforms.

documents.title: Who we are, who we aren't | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: When representing Moodle either as a team member or as part of our community, it's essential to reflect on who Moodle is and who we aren't. Avoid confrontation in our written, verbal, or other forms of communication.
documents.summary: This document outlines the professional tone and communication standards for representing Moodle, providing practical examples to ensure interactions remain approachable, sincere, and supportive.

documents.title: Word list | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This word list contains guidelines on how we use specific terms at Moodle.  If you can't find a word here, check the dictionary or use the search function to see if we've addressed it somewhere else in the guide.
documents.summary: This document provides a comprehensive word list and style guide for terminology used within the Moodle ecosystem to ensure consistency and accessibility in writing.

documents.title: Style guide | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Moodle Style Guide helps us create a clear and consistent approach to the content we produce: from our website, marketing, and communications to the actual text in Moodle products.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the key platforms within the Moodle ecosystem, including its main products, social resource sharing network, and professional development academy.

documents.title: The Moodle content guidelines | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Moodle content guidelines are for UX writers, copywriters, marketers, developers, translators, and anyone else writing for Moodle. By following these guidelines, you can help ensure that we're effective at communicating key messages to our users, and that we maintain consistency across all parts of the Moodle experience.
documents.summary: This document introduces the Moodle content guidelines designed to ensure consistent and effective communication for developers, writers, and marketers across all Moodle products.

documents.title: A better contribution: Comments in code | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The better contribution guide to writing comments in code
documents.summary: This document provides best practices and guidelines for writing meaningful code comments in Moodle, focusing on adding value by explaining intent and non-obvious details.

documents.title: Developer FAQ | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Help for new coders
documents.summary: This document serves as an introductory FAQ and resource guide for new Moodle developers, providing essential information on environment setup, coding standards, and core development processes. It directs users toward technical resources for database management, plugin creation, and community support channels.

documents.title: A better contribution: Fixup commits | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Using fixup commits when responding to review comments
documents.summary: This document outlines a Git workflow for balancing clean commit histories with the needs of code reviewers by using separate fixup branches and interactive rebasing.

documents.title: Making a better contribution | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: These guides provide advice on how to make a better contribution in software development - they're our 'ABC' guides to software development if you will. Most of the advice here is not Moodle-specific, and applies to software development in general.
documents.summary: This document introduces the 'A Better Contribution' series, providing general advice on improving software development practices through better communication, logical commits, and effective code review participation.

documents.title: Getting started | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: - Set up your development environment
documents.summary: This guide provides a comprehensive overview for new developers to set up their Moodle development environment and navigate the community contribution process. It covers essential tools, account setup, coding standards, and communication channels for starting Moodle development.

documents.title: Accessibility | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle is designed to provide equal functionality and information to all people. This means that there should be no barriers for people regardless of disabilities, assistive technologies that are used, different screen sizes and different input devices (for example mouse, keyboard and touchscreen).
documents.summary: This document outlines Moodle's commitment to web accessibility, detailing its conformance with WCAG standards, audit procedures, and the specific coding requirements for maintaining inclusive design across its products.

documents.title: Backporting | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Whilst we'd all like all Moodle users to be using our latest and greatest code, there is a balance to strike between improving our software and maintaining stability (both in terms of regressions, but also training and documentation materials). Large amounts of change on the stable branches make the lives difficult for institutions to manage upgrades between point releases.
documents.summary: This document outlines Moodle's official policy and procedures for backporting bug fixes, accessibility improvements, and new features to stable and long-term support branches. It provides specific guidelines for developers on how to request backports and the criteria used by the integration team for approval.

documents.title: Frankenstyle component names | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The term 'Frankenstyle component names' refers to the naming convention that is used to uniquely identify a Moodle plugin based on the type of plugin and its name.  They are used throughout the Moodle code (with a notable exception being the css class names in the themes).
documents.summary: This document defines the Frankenstyle naming convention used in Moodle to uniquely identify plugins and core subsystems across code, files, and databases.

documents.title: Moodle App Coding style | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Moodle App Coding Style guidelines
documents.summary: This document outlines specific coding style guidelines and exceptions for the Moodle App, focusing on TypeScript and Angular best practices to ensure code consistency and readability.

documents.title: SQL coding style | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes recommended coding style for complex database queries.
documents.summary: This document outlines the recommended coding style and best practices for writing SQL queries and fragments, focusing on parameterization and formatting for readability.

documents.title: Coding style | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Moodle Coding Style guidelines
documents.summary: This document outlines the mandatory PHP coding style and file formatting standards for Moodle developers to ensure code consistency and readability.

documents.title: Component Communication | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Moodle Coding Style guidelines
documents.summary: This document explains the structural architecture of Moodle, defining its core libraries, subsystems, and plugin types while establishing the rules for inter-component communication and dependencies.

documents.title: Icon deprecation | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Since Moodle 4.5, it's possible to safely deprecate and remove icons.
documents.summary: This document explains the procedures for deprecating and removing icons in Moodle 4.5 and later, covering registration methods for core and plugins as well as testing for deprecated icons using Behat.

documents.title: Plugin Removal | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: We regularly assess the standard plugins that are included in Moodle and will, from time-to-time, remove some of these.
documents.summary: This document outlines the policy and procedures for removing standard plugins from Moodle LMS, including notification channels, maintenance options for the community, and technical steps for repository extraction.

documents.title: SCSS deprecation | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Since Moodle 4.4, it's possible to deprecate SCSS styles and classes. This allows us to safely remove SCSS and will help us keep the code cleaner and more organized.
documents.summary: This document outlines the process for deprecating SCSS styles and classes in Moodle 4.4+, explaining how to use the deprecated.scss file and verify usage via Behat tests.

documents.title: Deprecation | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Deprecation, in its programming sense, is the process of taking older code and marking it as no longer being useful within the codebase, usually because it has been superseded by newer code. The deprecated code is not immediately removed from the codebase because doing so may cause regression errors.
documents.summary: This document explains the technical deprecation policy and multi-stage implementation process for the Moodle codebase, detailing how to phase out legacy code through specific lifecycle stages.

documents.title: Designing usable forms | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The following guidelines are intended to help you improve the user experience of both complex, and less complex, forms.
documents.summary: This document provides best practices for designing user-friendly forms and configuration pages, focusing on clear labeling, descriptive section naming, and logical organizational structure. It outlines strategies for improving the flow and usability of both simple and complex interfaces.

documents.title: Naming conventions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Components
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the primary websites and platforms within the Moodle ecosystem, including product information, resource sharing networks, and professional development courses.

documents.title: NodeJS | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Information about how NodeJS supported versions correlate with Moodle releases and the policy controlling it.
documents.summary: This document outlines Moodle's policy and procedures for maintaining and upgrading Node.js versions and project dependencies across supported software branches.

documents.title: PHP | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Information about how PHP supported versions correlate with Moodle releases and the policy controlling it.
documents.summary: This document outlines the policy for determining minimum and maximum supported PHP versions for Moodle releases and the requirements for upgrading between Long Term Support (LTS) versions.

documents.title: Brute-forcing login | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document explains how Moodle prevents brute-force login attacks through account lockout mechanisms and password complexity settings for administrators and developers.

documents.title: Buffer overruns and other platform weaknesses | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document explains the risks of buffer overruns at the server level for Moodle installations and outlines maintenance responsibilities for administrators to ensure system security.

documents.title: Command-line injection | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document explains the risks of command-line injection in Moodle and provides best practices for preventing it, such as using PHP libraries instead of shell commands and correctly escaping user input.

documents.title: Configuration information leakage | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document explains the security risks associated with revealing server software versions and technical details, offering guidance for developers and administrators to prevent information disclosure in Moodle.

documents.title: Cross-site request forgery | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document explains Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) risks in Moodle and provides instructions on using session keys (sesskey) and proper HTTP methods to secure web applications.

documents.title: Cross-site scripting | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document explains the risks of Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) in Moodle and provides instructions for developers and administrators on how to prevent these vulnerabilities using specific input cleaning and output escaping functions.

documents.title: Data-loss | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document outlines security and design best practices for preventing accidental or malicious data loss within Moodle development, emphasizing confirmation steps and risk assessment.

documents.title: Denial of service | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document outlines strategies for preventing and mitigating denial of service attacks in Moodle through logging, performance optimization, and server monitoring.

documents.title: Confidential information leakage | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document provides guidance on protecting personal user information in Moodle through appropriate permission checks, security vulnerability prevention, and administrative role configuration.

documents.title: Insecure configuration management | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document explains the risks of unauthorized code modifications and provides security guidelines for Moodle developers and administrators to protect their systems.

documents.title: Session fixation | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document explains session fixation attacks and outlines how Moodle mitigates these risks, providing security guidance for both developers and administrators.

documents.title: Social engineering | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: Explains the risks associated with social engineering and phishing in a Moodle environment, highlighting that these human-centric security threats require user education rather than technical fixes.

documents.title: SQL injection | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document explains the risks of SQL injection in Moodle and outlines the best practices for developers to prevent vulnerabilities using placeholders and parameter cleaning.

documents.title: Unauthenticated access | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: This document explains the principles of user authentication in Moodle and provides guidance for developers and administrators on implementing and configuring secure login processes.

documents.title: Unauthorised access | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page forms part of the Moodle security guidelines.
documents.summary: Explains Moodle's permission system using roles, capabilities, and contexts, providing guidance on how to implement access control within custom code.

documents.title: Security | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes how to write secure Moodle code that is not vulnerable to anything that evil people may try to throw at it.
documents.summary: This document provides a comprehensive overview of Moodle's security design philosophy and guidelines for developers to write code that prevents common web vulnerabilities.

documents.description: This is the top-level page describing Moodle's coding standards and guidelines.  It's the place to start if you want to know how to write code for Moodle.

It details the criteria for backporting fixes, maintaining backwards compatibility, and following the weekly integration schedule.

documents.description: The development of new features and improvements in the Moodle App is organised in the following six phases:
documents.summary: This document outlines the six-phase development lifecycle of the Moodle App, detailing the processes for feature prioritization, design, implementation, and quality assurance. It explains how Moodle HQ moves from initial discovery and stakeholder feedback through to final release and post-release evaluation.

documents.title: Accessibility checklist | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This document proposes a checklist for accessibility reviews. Not all aspects of accessibility can be checked automatically, so this checklist is intended to guide reviewers when doing an accessibility check to a patch.
documents.summary: This document provides a comprehensive checklist and set of guidelines for conducting accessibility reviews on code changes, covering automated testing, HTML/CSS standards, and usability requirements for assistive technologies.

documents.title: Peer review | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: All the information related to the peer-reviewing process during the Moodle development.
documents.summary: This document provides a comprehensive checklist and detailed guidelines for conducting peer reviews on Moodle code contributions to ensure quality, consistency, and compliance with project standards.

documents.description: 8 weeks prior

documents.title: Penetration testing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This is information for people who want to performing a penetration test of their Moodle instance as well as information for pen testers.
documents.summary: This document provides guidance for preparing a Moodle instance for penetration testing and explains common false positives related to XSS risks and CSRF tokens.

documents.title: Security procedures | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: In the Moodle software, security issues are treated very seriously. Even though a lot of time is dedicated designing the code to avoid such problems, it is inevitable in a project of this size that new vulnerabilities will occasionally be discovered.
documents.summary: This document outlines Moodle's responsible disclosure policy and provides instructions for reporting security vulnerabilities through the official submission form or issue tracker.

documents.title: Testing instructions guide | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page has suggestions for developers on how to write good testing instructions for the weekly testing of integrated issues.
documents.summary: This document provides a directory of Moodle's core platforms and services, including its learning management systems, resource-sharing network, and professional development academy.

documents.title: Testing of integrated issues | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: All the information related to the integration review process during the Moodle development.
documents.summary: This document outlines the procedures, roles, and technical requirements for testing Moodle code, covering the workflow from environment setup to issue resolution in the tracker.

documents.title: QA testing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: All the information related to the Qualify Assurance tests during the Moodle development.
documents.summary: This document outlines the procedures and guidelines for participating in Moodle's Quality Assurance (QA) testing cycles, including instructions on running tests, reporting bugs, and using the testing dashboard.

documents.title: Testing LMS issues in the mobile app | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Information related to mobile app testing of LMS issues
documents.summary: This document explains how to install and access the Moodle mobile app using various platforms and methods to facilitate the testing of LMS issues and local site developments.

documents.title: Testing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: All the information related to testing during the Moodle development.
documents.summary: This document provides a comprehensive overview of the manual and automated testing processes and tools used throughout the Moodle development lifecycle to ensure code quality and functionality.

documents.title: Bug triage | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Triage is a medical term referring to the process of prioritising patients based on the severity of their condition so as to maximise benefit (help as many as possible) when resources are limited.
documents.summary: This document outlines the procedures and criteria for the bug triage process in Moodle, explaining how to screen, prioritize, and manage tracker issues effectively.

documents.title: Development process | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A summary of the various development processes used in Moodle development.
documents.summary: This document outlines the collaborative development and integration workflow used for Moodle, detailing the specific roles, quality assurance processes, and release cycles involved in software maintenance.

documents.title: Working combinations of OS+Browser+selenium | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: As OS, Browsers and Selenium keeps updating, some combination might fail on different Moodle releases.
documents.summary: This document provides a compatibility matrix of supported operating systems, browsers, and Selenium driver versions for various Moodle releases to ensure successful automated testing.

documents.title: Browsers | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page complements Behat providing info about how to run the acceptance tests suite in different browsers.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for configuring and running Behat acceptance tests across different web browsers using Selenium drivers and PhantomJS. It covers driver installation, operating system-specific setup, and browser compatibility for specific test features.

documents.title: Running acceptance tests | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle uses Behat, a php framework for automated functional testing, as part of a suite of testing tools.
documents.summary: This document explains how to set up and run Behat automated functional tests within Moodle, covering system requirements, browser configuration, and Selenium integration.

documents.title: Writing acceptance tests | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This documentation gives some hints on writing behat tests for Moodle core, and for plugins. The focus of the documentation is on behat tests for plugins. Behat Features and Scenarios are written in a natural language, and should
documents.summary: This document provides instructions on writing Behat acceptance tests for Moodle plugins, covering the structure of feature files, scenarios, and the use of Given, When, and Then steps.

documents.title: Behat | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes the internals of Behat and the integration with Moodle.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Behat internals and details the framework's integration with Moodle for automated behavior-driven development and acceptance testing.

documents.title: Automated code review | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle issues submitted for review and inclusion into core are examined by our continuous integration (ci) system and checked against various automated tests. We use the automated checks to help improve the code quality in Moodle.
documents.summary: This document explains the role and functionality of CiBot, Moodle's automated code checking system, and outlines the processes for code quality reviews during development.

documents.title: Component Library | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Component Library is a tool designed for developers to identify frequently used user interface (UI) components and encourage their reuse within Moodle. It includes both components from Twitter Bootstrap and Moodle itself. The library provides an organized display of these components, showcasing them with your current Moodle theme.
documents.summary: This document introduces the Moodle Component Library, explaining how developers can access and build it to ensure UI consistency through reusable components. It provides step-by-step instructions for installation and outlines the requirements for documenting new interface elements.

documents.title: Composer | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Use composer to download Moodle code
documents.summary: This document explains how to use Composer to download Moodle and outlines the standard procedures for updating core dependencies and lock files to maintain environment stability.

documents.title: Exception Tracing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Exceptions, and errors are a fact of life as a developer, and dealing with them in development should be as easy and painless as possible.
documents.summary: This document explains how Moodle uses the Whoops library to display exceptions and debugging messages to developers, including configuration options for editors and error reporting levels.

documents.title: Generator tool | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Generator tool is a Moodle administration tool that allows you to generate test data for your Moodle site. It is helpful for testing and development purposes, as it can create a large number of users, courses, and other entities in a short time.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle Generator tool to create test courses, users, and scenarios for development and testing environments. It outlines the necessary developer requirements and provides instructions for execution via both web and command-line interfaces.

documents.title: GitHub Actions integration | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle core
documents.summary: This document explains how Moodle integrates with GitHub Actions to provide automated continuous integration testing for developers. It covers the setup, usage, and monitoring of build processes to identify unit test failures before code is submitted for integration.

documents.title: Gitpod | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Gitpod is a free, cloud-based platform with IDE integration that provides a suitable development environment directly in a browser.
documents.summary: This document explains how to set up and use Gitpod to create cloud-based development environments for Moodle, including integration with the Moodle Tracker for simplified testing and development.

documents.title: Moodle Development Kit | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Every developer creates simple tools to avoid repeating cumbersome and/or boring tasks, and that is precisely why MDK has been created: to pack all those useful tools in a portable way across systems. Initially developed in Bash, the project moved to Python to avoid dealing with inconsistencies between Unix platforms, and eventually to support Windows.
documents.summary: This document introduces MDK, a command-line toolkit for Moodle developers designed to automate instance management, installation, and common development workflows.

documents.title: Metadata | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle provides a variety of metadata which is used internally by Moodle, but which may also be useful in some developer tooling and integrations.
documents.summary: This document describes the various JSON metadata files used by Moodle to define its internal structure, including plugin types, subsystems, APIs, and standard plugins.

documents.title: NodeJS and Grunt | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle uses a NodeJS toolchain to perform a number of development actions, including linting, transpilation of JavaScript, compilation of the Component Library, and a number of other routine tasks.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for setting up the NodeJS development environment and Grunt build tool for Moodle. It covers installing NVM, managing dependencies with NPM, and using Grunt tasks for code transpilation, linting, and plugin development.

documents.title: PHP CodeSniffer | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: PHPCodeSniffer is a tool used to analyse PHP code using a set of rules. In many cases these rules can be used to automatically fix the errors they identify.
documents.summary: This document explains how to set up and use PHPCodeSniffer with Moodle's specific coding standards to analyze and fix PHP code. It covers installation via Composer, configuration of rulesets, and integration with various development environments.

documents.title: PHPUnit 11 Upgrade | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle 5.0 updated the version of PHPUnit from version 9.6 to version 11.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions and troubleshooting solutions for migrating Moodle unit tests from PHPUnit 9.6 to PHPUnit 11, covering breaking changes and deprecated methods.

documents.title: PHPUnit | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: PHPUnit by Sebastian Bergmann is an advanced unit testing framework for PHP. It is installed as Composer dependency and is not part of Moodle installation. To run PHPUnit tests, you have to manually install it on your development computer or test server.
documents.summary: This document provides comprehensive instructions for installing, configuring, and executing PHPUnit tests within a Moodle development environment.

documents.title: XMLDB editor | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Location: Site administration > Development > XMLDB editor
documents.summary: This document explains how to use Moodle's XMLDB editor to create and maintain database-neutral schema files for plugins. It provides instructions for managing tables, fields, and keys while adhering to Moodle's specific database conventions.

documents.title: Development tools | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A range of tools are available to make your life as a Moodle developer easier, and your development faster. These range from editor and IDE integrations, to linting tools which helps your code meet Moodle's Coding style, to build tools essential to the build process.
documents.summary: This document outlines the essential development tools for Moodle, focusing on PHP linting, JavaScript and CSS build processes, and general workflow enhancements. It aims to help developers maintain coding standards and increase efficiency through tools like PHPCodeSniffer, Grunt, and MDK.

documents.title: Tracker guide | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Moodle Tracker is our database for recording and managing all Moodle development issues - bugs, improvements and feature requests.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the Moodle Tracker system, outlining user permissions, group roles, and the specific fields used to manage bugs, improvements, and feature requests.

documents.title: Tracker issue labels | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Moodle Tracker allows issues to be labelled with tags. This page lists common labels that we use to flag aspects about our MDL issues (bugs and feature requests about Moodle itself).
documents.summary: This document defines the standard labels used in the Moodle Tracker for categorizing and managing issues, bugs, and feature requests. It explains the purpose of specific tags used during the triaging, documentation, and integration phases of the Moodle development process.

documents.title: Tracker tips and tricks | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Searching

documents.title: Tracker introduction | Moodle Developer Resources

documents.summary: This document provides instructions on how to use the Moodle Tracker for reporting, searching, and managing software bugs and feature requests. It also outlines best practices for creating high-quality issues and explains the workflow for assigning tasks within the Moodle development community.

documents.description: Moodle encourages developers to note any important API changes which may impact other developers in that components Upgrade notes.
