documents.title: Markdown page example | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: You don't need React to write simple standalone pages.
documents.summary: This document provides a brief overview and directory of key websites within the Moodle ecosystem, covering products, resource sharing, and professional training.

documents.title: Technical requirements | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle is a PHP Application, which is backed by a relational database.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview and navigation links to the primary platforms within the Moodle ecosystem, including product information, resource sharing, and professional development services.

documents.title: Bootstrap 5 migration | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Bootstrap 5 has evolved with new features, improvements, and changes in its latest version, and along with this some breaking changes also come, which need to be addressed in the migration process.
documents.summary: This document outlines the multi-step process for migrating from Bootstrap 4 to Bootstrap 5, detailing specific CSS class changes, component refactors, and the implementation of a compatibility bridge. It provides developers with guidance on replacing deprecated features with version 5-compatible alternatives.

documents.title: Git for developers | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A reasonable knowledge of the Git basics is a good idea before you start to use it for development. If you are new to Git, you are encouraged to go to the See also section on this page for some more general reading.
documents.summary: This guide outlines the standard Git workflow and setup procedures for Moodle developers, including installation, configuration, and repository management. It describes the lifecycle of a code contribution from local development to integration into the Moodle production repository.

documents.title: Developer guides | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Getting started guides to Moodle features
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the various platforms and services within the Moodle ecosystem, including its core LMS products, resource sharing network, and training academy.

documents.title: JavaScript | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle makes heavy use of JavaScript to improve the experience for its users.
documents.summary: This document introduces the core concepts and standards for writing JavaScript in Moodle, focusing on ES2015 modules, naming conventions, and event handling.

documents.title: AJAX | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The preferred way to write new ajax interactions in Moodle is to use the JavaScript module core/ajax which directly calls web service functions built using the Moodle Web Service API.
documents.summary: This guide explains how to implement AJAX interactions in Moodle using the core/ajax JavaScript module to interact with the Web Service API. It covers service definition in PHP, repository patterns for JavaScript, and security considerations such as data filtering and session requirements.

documents.title: Combobox searching | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A combobox search component has been added to the core Moodle system. This component provides an additional layer of search functionality, allowing users to easily navigate and filter search results. The combobox search component is designed to be reusable and can be integrated into various areas of the Moodle platform.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and extend the Moodle core combobox search component to create consistent and maintainable search interfaces across the platform.

documents.title: Example usages | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Core Search Dropdown Migration
documents.summary: This document outlines the migration of Moodle grade report modules to the core search dropdown component and provides a code example for developers to implement it in custom plugins.

documents.title: jQuery | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A description of how and when to use jQuery in Moodle
documents.summary: This document outlines Moodle's policies and implementation methods for jQuery and jQuery UI, emphasizing that native ES6 modules are preferred and jQuery use is discouraged for new development.

documents.title: Modal Dialogues | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The use of modal modules provides a simplified developer experience for creating modal dialogues within Moodle.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions on creating and managing accessible modal dialogues in Moodle using JavaScript modules, including standard modal types and custom implementations.

documents.title: Modules | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A JavaScript module is a package of code that can be reliably used and shared with other code in a reusable format.
documents.summary: This document explains how to develop and implement JavaScript modules in Moodle, focusing on the transition from AMD to ESM format and the associated build tools.

documents.title: Creating a reactive UI | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Third-party plugin developers are free to use any framework they want to implement reactive interfaces like React, Angular or Vue. However, for now Moodle does not provide any of them and all core developments are framework independent.
documents.summary: This document explains Moodle's internal reactive UI library and how to implement framework-independent reactive interfaces using state management and the BaseComponent class. It outlines the core principles of components, mutations, and the unique source of truth for maintaining UI consistency.

documents.title: YUI | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: As of Moodle 2.9 we are transitioning away from YUI to AMD modules. This transition will take a long time, but it is important because the YUI team have stopped all new development on the YUI library. See JavaScript Modules for more information.
documents.summary: This document explains how Moodle utilizes the YUI framework for JavaScript development, covering modular architecture, development tools like Grunt and JSHint, and specific configuration settings for debugging.

documents.title: YUI Modules | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: As of Moodle 2.9 we are transitioning away from YUI to AMD modules. This transition will take a long time, but it is important because the YUI team have stopped all new development on the YUI library. See JavaScript Modules for more information.
documents.summary: This document explains how to create and implement YUI modules in Moodle, covering naming conventions, directory structure, and integration with PHP code.

documents.title: YUI Namespacing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: As of Moodle 2.9 we are transitioning away from YUI to AMD modules. This transition will take a long time, but it is important because the YUI team have stopped all new development on the YUI library. See JavaScript Modules for more information.
documents.summary: This document defines the naming convention and rationale for namespacing YUI modules within Moodle to ensure effective sandboxing and consistency across core and third-party plugins.

documents.title: Profiling PHP | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: PHP has two types of profiler:
documents.summary: This document explains how to set up and use XHProf and Xdebug profilers to monitor and optimize PHP performance within a Moodle environment.

documents.title: Templates | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A guide to the features and use of Mustache templating in Moodle.
documents.summary: This document explains how Moodle uses the Mustache template system for HTML rendering, covering basic syntax, sections, partials, and Moodle-specific helpers.

documents.title: Plugin Upgrades | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Upgrade API is a core API which allows your plugin to manage features of its own installation, and upgrade. Every plugin includes a version which allows the Upgrade API to apply only the required changes.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Upgrade API, detailing how plugins manage installations and database migrations through versioning and specific PHP and XML files.

documents.title: Common files | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes the common files which may be present in any Moodle subsystem or plugin type. Some of these files are mandatory and must exist within a component, whilst others are optional.
documents.summary: This document outlines the mandatory and optional files within Moodle plugins and subsystems, explaining their roles in versioning, localization, global functions, and database schema management.

documents.title: db/tasks.php | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A description of the plugin scheduled task configuration file
documents.summary: This document explains how to define and configure scheduled tasks for Moodle plugins using the tasks.php file and specific scheduling properties.

documents.title: tag.php | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A description of the library tag.php file, describing what plugins have tags where their callbacks are located.
documents.summary: This document defines the structure and attributes for specifying tag areas in Moodle, allowing components to register taggable entities and their associated behaviors. It provides a reference for the $tagareas array configuration used to link database tables with the tagging system.

documents.title: version.php | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A description of the plugin version.php file, describing the various features
documents.summary: This document explains the purpose and configuration of the version.php file required for all Moodle plugins, detailing properties used for installation, upgrades, and compatibility checks.

documents.title: Core APIs | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle provides a series of Core APIs which can be used by any part of Moodle.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the various platforms and services within the Moodle ecosystem, including product information, resource sharing networks, and professional development courses.

documents.title: Activity completion API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: There are changes to the completion API introduced in Moodle 3.11 to be incorporated to this page. Please refer to Student activity completion for details.
documents.summary: This document provides technical instructions for developers to implement the activity completion system in Moodle activity modules, including view-based, grade-based, and custom completion rules. It details the required functions, database updates, and backup procedures needed to integrate a plugin with Moodle's completion tracking API.

documents.title: Calendar API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page documents the Calendar API as it is in Moodle 3.3 and later. For the API in older versions of Moodle, see Calendar API old.
documents.summary: This document provides a technical guide for using the Moodle Calendar API to manage user, group, and course events, including the implementation of dashboard action events.

documents.title: Clock | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Fetching the current time
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement the PSR-20 compatible Clock interface in Moodle using dependency injection to replace the standard time function. It details how this approach improves unit testing by allowing developers to mock frozen or incrementing time states.

documents.title: Conditional activities API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Conditional Activities API allowsyou to specify whether to hide, or show, an activity when a series of conditions associated with it are met.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Conditional Activities API, which manages the availability and visibility of course activities based on specific criteria like grades, dates, or completion status.

documents.title: Custom fields API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Custom fields API overview
documents.summary: This document provides a technical overview of the Custom Fields API, detailing how to define custom field areas, implement handler classes, and integrate custom fields into plugin forms. It also covers data retrieval methods and compliance requirements for the Privacy API.

documents.title: Deprecation API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: When deprecating a code feature, it is often desirable to include a reasonable amount of information, and to provide a consistent deprecation message.
documents.summary: This document demonstrates how to use the Moodle core deprecated attribute to mark functions, classes, and enum cases as obsolete with specific metadata such as replacement, version, and reasoning.

documents.title: Dependency Injection | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The use of PSR-11 compatible Dependency Injection in Moodle
documents.summary: This document explains the implementation and usage of PSR-11 compatible Dependency Injection in Moodle, covering constructor injection, manual fetching, and mocking dependencies for unit testing.

documents.title: Data manipulation API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes the functions available to access data in the Moodle database. You should exclusively use these functions in order to retrieve or modify database content because these functions provide a high level of abstraction and guarantee that your database manipulation will work against different RDBMSes.
documents.summary: This document outlines the Moodle Data Manipulation API, explaining how to use the global $DB object to interact with the database in a secure and cross-platform compatible manner.

documents.title: Database schema | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The files available here are in DBDesigner4 format. DBDesigner4 is a schema drawing program released under GPL.
documents.summary: This document provides a directory of the various platforms and services within the Moodle ecosystem, including its core LMS products, resource-sharing networks, and professional development courses.

documents.title: Data definition API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: In this page you'll access to the available functions under Moodle to be able to handle DB structures (tables, fields, indexes...).
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the Data Definition Language (DDL) functions in Moodle used to manage database structures like tables, fields, and indexes during installation and upgrade processes.

documents.title: Transactions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle allows data manipulation to take place within a database transaction, known as a Delegated transaction. This allows you to perform CRUD operations, and roll them back if a failure takes place.
documents.summary: This document outlines the principles and API usage for delegated database transactions in Moodle, explaining how to manage nested CRUD operations and ensure data integrity through rollbacks.

documents.title: DML drivers | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A number of native drivers are included with Moodle, including those with support for:
documents.summary: This document outlines the native database drivers supported by Moodle and provides instructions for configuring query logging features within the DML driver layer.

documents.title: DML exceptions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The DML API uses a selection of exceptions to indicate errors.
documents.summary: This document provides a directory of key platforms within the Moodle ecosystem, including its core products, social network for educational resources, and professional training academy.

documents.title: Advanced grading API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Advanced grading was introduced in Moodle 2.2 for grading of assignments. It is intended to be used for grading of other types of activities in the later versions.
documents.summary: This document explains the core architecture of Moodle's advanced grading system and provides technical instructions for implementing it within grade-able modules.

documents.title: Hooks API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes the Hooks API which is a replacement for some of the lib.php based one-to-many
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Hooks API, a PSR-14 compliant system for inter-plugin communication that replaces legacy lib.php callbacks. It covers the creation, registration, and dispatching of hooks within the Moodle framework.

documents.title: HTML Writer API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle has a class called HTML writer which allows you to output basic HTML tags. This is typically used within renderer functions, for example question/type/pluginname/renderer.php.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle HTML writer class to programmatically generate HTML tags and attributes within PHP renderer functions.

documents.title: Lock API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Locking is required whenever you need to prevent two, or more, processes accessing the same resource at the same time. The prime candidate for locking in Moodle is cron. Locking allows multiple cron processes to work on different parts of cron at the same time with no risk that they will conflict (work on the same job at the same time).
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle locking API, providing guidance on how to manage concurrent resource access using the lock factory and code implementation.

documents.title: Message API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: What is this document?
documents.summary: This document provides technical instructions for using the Moodle Messaging API to programmatically send notifications and messages from plugins or blocks. It details how to register message producers, configure notification defaults, and implement the message_send function.

documents.title: Navigation API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Navigation API allows for the manipulation of the navigation system used in Moodle.
documents.summary: This document explains the architecture and implementation of the Moodle Navigation API, detailing how to manage navigation, settings, and breadcrumbs through the global page object.

documents.title: Preference API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Preference API is used for the storage and retrieval of user preferences. These preferences are stored in the database for users with an account, however for guests or users who are not currently logged in the preferences are stored in the Session.
documents.summary: This document explains the Preference API used for storing and retrieving user-specific data in either the database or session. It details the primary PHP functions for managing user preferences and provides best practices for their implementation.

documents.title: Report builder API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Overview
documents.summary: This document explains the architecture and implementation of the Report Builder API, detailing how to define and configure report columns, filters, and reusable entities.

documents.title: Setting default conditions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: When setting up a datasource it is possible to define the default condition values for it using the getdefaultcondition_values() method.
documents.summary: Explains how to configure default filter values in a report datasource using the get_default_condition_values method, covering various filter types and their specific operator requirements.

documents.title: User-related APIs | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This is a collection of miscellaneous APIs that can help with doing things with lists of users.
documents.summary: This document outlines Moodle APIs for managing user data, including methods for displaying profile information, validating and cleaning user fields, and implementing user selection widgets.

documents.title: API Guides | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle has a number of core APIs that provide tools for Moodle scripts.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Moodle's core and general APIs essential for developing plugins, covering systems like database manipulation, user access, and file handling.

documents.title: Plugin types | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle is a powerful, and very extensible, Learning Management System. One of its core tenets is its extensibility, and this is primarily achieved through the development of plugins.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Moodle's plugin system, detailing naming conventions, validation rules, and the various plugin types available for extending the platform.

documents.title: AI Plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The AI subsystem provides a way for developers to integrate external AI services into Moodle LMS.
documents.summary: This document explains the architecture of the Moodle AI subsystem, detailing the distinct roles of provider and placement plugins in integrating external AI services.

documents.title: Placements | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Placements provide a consistent UX and UI for users when they use AI backed functionality (e.g. generating an image).
documents.summary: This document explains how to develop and implement AI Placement plugins within the Moodle AI subsystem to provide user interfaces for AI actions while maintaining separation from AI providers.

documents.title: Providers | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Providers are the interface between the AI subsystem and external AI.
documents.summary: This document explains how to develop and implement AI Provider plugins for the Moodle AI subsystem, detailing the required class structures, processing logic, and configuration settings. It outlines the architectural relationship between Providers, Managers, and Placements to ensure consistent communication with external AI services.

documents.title: Antivirus plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Integrate your preferred Antivirus tool to with Moodle to automatically check new file uploads.
documents.summary: This document provides a technical guide for developing antivirus plugins in Moodle, detailing the required file structure and mandatory class implementations for file scanning.

documents.title: Assignment sub-plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The mod_assign activity can be extended using two sub-plugin types, namely:
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the core platforms within the Moodle ecosystem, including its main LMS products, resource-sharing social network, and training academy.

documents.title: Assign feedback plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Assign feedback plugins allow you to define different ways that a teacher can provide feedback to their students.
documents.summary: This guide provides a technical overview of creating Moodle assignment feedback plugins, detailing the required file structure, naming conventions, and class methods.

documents.title: Assign submission plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Assign submission plugins allow you to define different ways for a student to submit their work
documents.summary: This document provides a technical overview and implementation guide for creating Moodle assignment submission plugins, detailing file structure, naming constraints, and core class methods.

documents.title: Atto | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Atto is a JavaScript text editor built specifically for Moodle. It is the default text editor in Moodle from 2.7 onwards, and is implemented as a standard Moodle text editor plugin. Most of the code is written in JavaScript using YUI modules.
documents.summary: This document provides a boilerplate implementation for creating and configuring custom toolbar buttons within Moodle's Atto text editor using the YUI framework.

documents.title: Availability conditions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Availability conditions allow teachers to restrict an activity or section so that only certain users can access it. These are accessed using the Availability API.
documents.summary: This document explains how to develop availability condition plugins for Moodle, detailing the directory structure and the PHP classes required to implement custom access restrictions.

documents.title: Block plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Block plugins allow you to show supplemental information, and features, within different parts of Moodle.
documents.summary: This document outlines the file structure and mandatory components required to develop block plugins in Moodle, covering the block definition class, access control, and metadata files.

documents.title: Communication plugin | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Communication plugin allows you to create a communication provider plugin, which can be added as a part of course or any other instances.
documents.summary: Explains how to develop and implement communication provider plugins, detailing the required file structure and the PHP interfaces used to manage communication rooms and user synchronization.

documents.title: Custom fields | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Custom fields allow you to create field types to be used for custom fields. Instances of these field types can be added to the respective areas that implement Custom fields API. Currently in Moodle core only courses implement this API, however custom fields are also used in addon plugins for other areas. For example, if you want to display radio buttons on the course edit page, then you can add an instance of a radio custom field plugin to the Course custom fields configuration.
documents.summary: This PHP class defines the configuration form and behavior for custom field types in Moodle by extending the core field controller.

documents.title: Enrolment plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle provides a number of ways of managing course enrolment, called enrolment plugins. Each course can decide its enabled enrolment plugins instances and any enrolment plugin can define a workflow the user must follow in order to enrol in the course.
documents.summary: This document explains the technical architecture, file structure, and implementation requirements for developing custom enrolment plugins in Moodle.

documents.title: File Converters | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: File converters are an important tool to support other plugins with file conversion supported between a wide range of file formats. File converters are accessed using the File conversion API and are typically consumed by other plugins rather than by the user directly.
documents.summary: Provides technical instructions for creating file converter plugins in Moodle, including file structure requirements and the implementation of mandatory conversion methods.

documents.title: Filter plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Filters are a way to automatically transform content before it is output. Filters may be used to:
documents.summary: This document explains how to create and implement filter plugins in Moodle to automatically transform text content before it is displayed. It covers the mandatory file structure, the text_filter class implementation, and performance best practices for developers.

documents.title: Course format | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Course formats are plugins that determine the layout of course resources.
documents.summary: This document explains the structure and implementation of Moodle course format plugins, detailing how they control course layouts, section organization, and navigation through specific PHP files and classes.

documents.title: Migrating 3.11 formats | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The new course editor introduced in Moodle 4.0 reimplements most of the previous webservices, AMD modules, and internal logic of the course rendering. However, all formats since 3.11 will use the previous libraries by default until its final deprecation in Moodle 4.3. This document collects the main adaptations any 3.11 course format will require to continue working when this happens.
documents.summary: This document outlines the architectural changes in the Moodle 4.0 course editor and provides technical guidance for adapting legacy course format plugins to the new reactive component system.

documents.title: Local plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The recommended way to add new functionality to Moodle is to create a new standard plugin (for example, activity, block, authentication, enrol). The local plugin-type is mostly suitable for things that do not fit into these standard plugin types.
documents.summary: This document explains how to programmatically add a custom link to the Moodle course administration menu using a local plugin hook.

documents.title: Logstore plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle supports the ability to define a custom log storage system using the logstore plugin type. This hasn't been documented yet - perhaps you are able to help us.
documents.summary: This document provides a high-level overview of the Moodle ecosystem, directing users to information on its core products, resource-sharing network, and professional development platforms.

documents.title: Machine learning backends | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Machine learning backends process the datasets generated from the indicators and targets calculated by the Analytics API. They are used for machine learning training, prediction and models evaluation.
documents.summary: This document explains the architecture and implementation of machine learning backends in Moodle, detailing how they interact with the Analytics API to process datasets for training and prediction.

documents.title: Activity modules | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Activity modules are a fundamental course feature and are usually the primary delivery method for learning content in Moodle.
documents.summary: This document outlines how to implement the activity creation and configuration form for a Moodle plugin module using the moodleform_mod class.

documents.title: Activity chooser | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This documentation is from the project kick-off and has not been updated since the project completed.
documents.summary: This document outlines the redesign of the Moodle activity chooser interface and explains the new callbacks required for third-party plugin developers to support features like starring and recommendations.

documents.title: Module visibility and display | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Summary
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle API for customizing how course modules are displayed and accessed on course pages, including methods for caching metadata and rendering dynamic user-specific content.

documents.title: Book activity sub-plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The mod_book activity can be extended using the tool sub-plugin type. This hasn't been documented yet - perhaps you are able to help us.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the Moodle ecosystem, detailing its core products, resource-sharing network, and professional development academy.

documents.description: The mod_data activity can be extended using two sub-plugin types, namely:
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the primary platforms and services within the Moodle ecosystem, including its core LMS products, resource-sharing network, and professional development academy.

documents.title: Database fields | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Database activity included with Moodle includes support for several predefined field types, including text, date, and URL. It is also possible to create new field types. For example, you might like to create:
documents.summary: Explains how to develop custom field type sub-plugins for the Moodle Database activity, covering directory structure, mandatory files, and class methods for field behavior.

documents.title: Database presets | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The database preset subplugin type is no longer recommended.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the core components and services within the Moodle ecosystem, including its learning management products, social networking platform, and training resources.

documents.title: Forum activity sub-plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The mod_forum activity can be extended using the forumreport sub-plugin type. This hasn't been documented yet - perhaps you are able to help us.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the various platforms and services within the Moodle ecosystem, including its core products, social networking for resources, and professional development academy.

documents.title: Question bank plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Question bank plugins allow you to extend the functionality of the Moodle Question bank.
documents.summary: This document explains how to extend Moodle's question bank functionality through plugins, detailing available extension points and the implementation of the plugin features class.

documents.title: Question bank filters | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Question bank plugins allow you to define new filters for the question bank view and random question sets.
documents.summary: This document explains how to create and customize filter conditions for question bank plugins by implementing PHP condition classes and frontend JavaScript filters.

documents.title: Question type plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Question type plugins implement the different types of question that the core Question subsystem can handle.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the primary websites and services within the Moodle ecosystem, including its products, resource sharing network, and professional development academy.

documents.title: Defaults for new questions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A way for question types to remember a user's preferred settings for creating questions of a given type.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement a feature that saves user preferences as default settings for new question types, ensuring consistency across the question creation process.

documents.title: Repository plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Repository plugin allow Moodle to bring contents into Moodle from external repositories.
documents.summary: This document outlines the requirements and file structure for developing Moodle repository plugins, including mandatory files like version.php and lib.php.

documents.title: SMS gateway | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: SMS gateway plugins allow you to create SMS gateway providers.
documents.summary: This PHP code provides the implementation for an AWS SNS SMS gateway, detailing the methods for formatting recipient numbers and dispatching messages through the service.

documents.title: Theme plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A Moodle theme allows users to customize the appearance and functionality of their Moodle site, from overall design to specific activities. Users can create their own themes or modify existing ones, leveraging CSS and JavaScript for customization. The theme architecture ensures smooth fallbacks for minimal changes, fostering flexibility and ease of use.
documents.summary: This document defines the configuration settings for the Moodle Boost theme, specifying page layouts, block regions, SCSS processing callbacks, and user interface behaviors.

documents.title: Fonts | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: CSS3 standard introduced the possibility to specify custom fonts, see CSS web fonts tutorial.
documents.summary: This document provides technical instructions on implementing custom fonts in Moodle, covering file location conventions, supported formats, and CSS placeholder syntax for themes and plugins.

documents.title: Images and icons in themes | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: One of the theme features is the ability to override any of the standard images within Moodle when your theme is in use. At this point, let's explore how to utilize your own images within your theme and how to override the images being used by Moodle.
documents.summary: This document explains how to manage, use, and override images within Moodle themes, covering directory structures, template integration, and CSS implementation.

documents.title: Layout | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: All themes are required to define the layouts they wish to be responsible for as well as create; however, many layout files are required by those layouts. If the theme is overriding another theme then it is a case of deciding which layouts this new theme should override. If the theme is a completely fresh start then you will need to define a layout for each of the different possibilities.
documents.summary: This document explains how to define and configure page layouts in Moodle themes, covering layout settings in config.php and the implementation of layout files using PHP and Mustache templates.

documents.title: Styles | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Let's begin by exploring the various locations within Moodle from which CSS can be included:
documents.summary: This document explains how CSS and SCSS are integrated into Moodle themes, detailing file locations, pre-processor usage, and the system of unique body IDs and classes used for page-specific styling.

documents.title: TinyMCE Editor Plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle includes the TinyMCE text editor as standard from Moodle 4.1, and it can be installed from the plugins database for Moodle versions 3.11, and 4.0.
documents.summary: This document provides a comprehensive guide on developing subplugins for the TinyMCE editor in Moodle, detailing the required file structure and the implementation of key JavaScript components.

documents.title: Testing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Testing is an important part of development and we strongly encourage you to write appropriate tests for your plugins.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions and best practices for writing Behat tests for TinyMCE editor plugins in Moodle, detailing required tags and specific steps for interacting with the editor UI.

documents.title: Access API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Access API gives you functions so you can determine what the current user is allowed to do. It also allows plugins to extend Moodle with new capabilities.
documents.summary: This document explains Moodle's role-based access control system and how developers can use the Access API to define and check user permissions within various contexts.

documents.title: Admin settings | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle's configuration is stored in a mixture of the config, config_plugins, and a few other tables. These settings are edited through the administration screens, which can be accessed by going to the .../admin/index.php URL on your moodle site, or using the Administration block that appears to administrators of the Moodle front page. This page explains how the code for displaying and editing of these settings works.
documents.summary: This document explains the internal architecture of Moodle's administration settings system, detailing how the object-oriented settings tree is constructed and how plugins register custom configuration options.

documents.title: AI Subsystem | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The AI Subsystem in Moodle LMS provides a consistent and user-friendly way for users to interact with AI
documents.summary: This document outlines the architectural design and core components of the Moodle AI Subsystem, explaining how placements, providers, and actions interact through a central manager.

documents.title: Analytics API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Analytics API allows managers to use predictions to detect trends and predict student behaviour
documents.summary: This document explains the architecture and implementation of the Moodle Analytics API, focusing on how to define prediction models, indicators, and targets within the learning management system.

documents.title: Availability API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The availability API controls access to activities and sections. For example, a teacher could restrict access so that an activity cannot be accessed until a certain date, or so that a section cannot be accessed unless users have a certain grade in a quiz.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle Availability API to manage and restrict access to course activities and sections based on specific criteria. It covers checking visibility permissions for users, filtering user lists, and programmatically configuring access conditions.

documents.title: Backup API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Backup API provides a way to include your plugin's in the course backup. See Restore API for the part that takes care of restoring data.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement the Backup API in Moodle plugins to include custom data in course backups, detailing the required file structures and class hierarchies for activity modules and blocks.

documents.title: Restore API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Restore API provides a way to restore your plugin's data from a backup file created in Moodle 2.0 or later. For the information on how backup files are created, see Backup API. For the information on how to support restoring data from backup files created in Moodle 1.x, see Backup conversion API.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement the Moodle Restore API to recover plugin data from backup files using restore plans, tasks, and steps.

documents.title: Check API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A Check is a runtime test to make sure that something is working well. You can think of Checks as similar and complimentary to the PHPUnit and Acceptance testing but the next layer around them, and performed at run time rather than development, or build time.
documents.summary: This document describes the Moodle Check API, a framework for conducting runtime tests to verify system health, security, and configuration. It explains the various types of checks, their possible result states, and how developers can create custom checks for their plugins.

documents.title: Communication API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Communication API provides access to the messaging system and other communication providers (such as Matrix).
documents.summary: This document explains the technical architecture and public methods of the Communication API for managing messaging rooms and memberships through asynchronous tasks and hooks.

documents.title: Editor API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The editor API lets you control Moodle text editors. It can be found in lib/editorlib.php.
documents.summary: This document explains how to programmatically initialize and configure Moodle text editors using the Editor API and the use_editor function.

documents.title: Enrolment API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The enrolment API gives access to the enrolment methods and also to enrolment plugins instances.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Enrolment API, detailing the core functions and plugin methods used to manage user participation, course access, and the distinction between enrolments and role assignments.

documents.title: External Services | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle has a full-featured Web Service framework, allowing you to use and create web services for use in external systems.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Moodle's Web Service framework and External API, serving as a central hub for developer resources on creating, implementing, and managing web services.

documents.title: Service creation | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle comes with two built-in services that your functions can be attached to.
documents.summary: This document outlines the configuration structure for defining external web services, including function registration, capability requirements, and file access permissions.

documents.title: Function Declarations | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Before they can be used, all functions must be declared to Moodle, and their inputs and outputs must be defined.
documents.summary: This document provides a PHP code snippet for defining a web service function in a Moodle plugin, detailing parameters such as class names, access types, and service integration.

documents.title: File handling | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle provides two ways to fetch and upload files:
documents.summary: This document provides technical instructions on how to handle file transfers in Moodle using web service functions and dedicated upload/download endpoints.

documents.title: Function Definitions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: An External function definition is the class, and collection of functions, used to define:
documents.summary: This document defines a PHP class for a Moodle external API function that enables the programmatic creation of course groups, specifying input parameters, security checks, and return structures.

documents.title: Security | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Before operating on any data in an external function, you must ensure that the user:
documents.summary: This document outlines the essential security and validation steps for Moodle external functions, including parameter verification, context validation, and capability checks.

documents.title: Unit Testing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Unit tests are the best way of checking the behaviour of your external services and can help you to:
documents.summary: This document provides unit tests for validating the capability checks and execution logic of a Moodle external service function.

documents.title: Writing a new service | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This documentation covers the creation of a new external service for use in a web service of a fictional local plugin, local_groupmanager.
documents.summary: This document explains the process of creating and declaring external web service functions for Moodle plugins, covering naming conventions, service definitions, and the implementation of parameter and return value structures.

documents.title: Favourites API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Overview
documents.summary: This document describes the Favourites API, explaining how to mark, retrieve, and delete user-specific bookmarks for various system items. It details the required identification fields and provides instructions for integrating favourite data into database queries.

documents.title: File API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The File API is used to control, manage, and serve all files uploaded and stored within Moodle. This page covers the core File API, which is responsible for storage, retrieval, and serving of files stored in Moodle.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the Moodle File API, detailing how files are organized into areas and explaining the process for generating URLs and serving files through plugin callbacks.

documents.title: File Browser API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The File Browser API is a supplemental API which can be used to fetch information relating to Files stored in the Moodle File API.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle File Browser API to retrieve metadata and hierarchical path information for files stored within the Moodle File API.

documents.title: File Converters | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Users are able to submit a wide range of files, and it is a common requirement to convert these to alternative formats.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle file converter API to transform documents between formats and manage conversion statuses asynchronously.

documents.title: File API internals | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The goals of the File API are to:
documents.summary: This document outlines the architecture and core components of Moodle's File API, explaining how it handles file storage, metadata, and serving through a consistent interface. It details the use of content hashing for deduplication and the various sub-APIs responsible for file management and user interface integration.

documents.title: Forms API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Form are created using the Form API. The Form API supports most standard HTML elements, including checkboxes, radio buttons, text boxes, and so on, adding additional accessibility and security features to them.
documents.summary: This document explains how to create, define, and process web forms in Moodle using the Form API, covering both the definition of form classes and the handling of submitted data.

documents.title: Advanced elements | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Form elements can be marked as 'advanced'. This has the effect that they are hidden initially.
documents.summary: This document explains how to hide form elements or sections in Moodle by marking them as advanced using the setAdvanced method.

documents.title: Checkbox controller | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The checkbox controller allows developers to group checkboxes together and add a link or button to check, or uncheck, all of the checkboxes at once.
documents.summary: This document demonstrates how to implement checkbox controllers in Moodle forms to manage group selection and deselection for advanced checkboxes.

documents.title: No submit button | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The moodleform 'nosubmitbutton_pressed()' method allows you to detect if a button on your form has been pressed that is a submit button but that has been defined as a button that doesn't result in a processing of all the form data but will result in some form 'sub action' and then having the form redisplayed. This is useful for example to have an 'Add' button to add some option to a select box in the form etc. You define a button as a no submit button as in the example below (in definition()). This example adds a text box and a submit button in a group.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and handle non-submitting buttons in Moodle forms using the no_submit_button_pressed method to trigger sub-actions without full form processing.

documents.title: Repeat elements | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Form API includes the ability to repeat a group of form elements. This is useful where you need to have an unknown quantity of item data, for example possible answers in a quiz question.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Form API's repeat_elements method to create dynamic, repeating groups of form fields for handling variable quantities of user input.

documents.title: Choice Dropdown | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The choicedropdown form field creates a dropdown list with multiple options. It is different from a standard select dropdown in that each option can have extra icons and descriptions. This field is often used in forms to facilitate the selection of a non-trivial option that demands additional information.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement the choicedropdown form field and the choicelist data definition to create enhanced selection menus with icons and descriptions.

documents.title: Form Usage | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle's Form API is an extension of the Pear HTMLQuickForm API, which is no longer supported. Some documentation for the upstream library is available in the PEAR package page, including a short tutorial. A longer tutorial is also available, courtesy of the Internet Archive.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Moodle's Form API, detailing how to create, define, and process web forms within the Moodle framework using the moodleform class.

documents.title: Files in Forms | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Files and their metadata are stored within the File API. Each file within the API is associated with:
documents.summary: This guide explains how to use Moodle form elements like filepicker, filemanager, and editors to handle user file uploads and manage their lifecycle within the Moodle File API.

documents.title: Groups API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle Groups are a way of expressing collections of users within a course. They may be defined by the teacher in the course participants page, or created automatically during a bulk user upload (for example, from a text file).
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Groups API and how developers can implement group support and access control within activity modules. It covers group modes, visibility settings, and core functions for managing user collections and groupings.

documents.title: Cache API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This document provides an in-depth overview of the Cache API, also known as MUC (Moodle Universal Cache), a fundamental caching system within Moodle.
documents.summary: This document provides a comprehensive guide to the Moodle Universal Cache (MUC) API, explaining how to define cache areas, manage storage modes, and perform basic data operations within plugins.

documents.title: Output API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Output API is responsible for visual aspects of Moodle content. This page explains how renderers, renderables, themes and templates all work together.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Output API, detailing how renderers, renderables, and templates work together to generate and manage visual content within the Moodle framework.

documents.title: Inplace editable | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The inplace_editable element is a mini-API which allows developers to easily support editing of a value on any page. The interface is used in places such as the course section and activity name editing.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement the Moodle inplace_editable mini-API to enable inline editing of values within custom plugins.

documents.title: Plagiarism API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Overview
documents.summary: This document provides a directory of key platforms within the Moodle ecosystem, including product information, resource sharing networks, and professional development courses.

documents.title: Privacy API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is an EU directive that provides users with more control over their data and how it is processed. This regulation came into effect on 25th of May 2018 and covers any citizen or permanent resident of the European Union. The directive is respected by a number of other countries outside of the European Union.
documents.summary: This document provides technical guidance for Moodle plugin developers to implement the core_privacy subsystem API, ensuring compliance with GDPR requirements for data access and deletion.

documents.title: FAQs | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: My plugin sends notifications or messages to the user - do I need to return this user data?
documents.summary: This document provides guidance for Moodle developers on handling user data and privacy compliance across various plugin types. it clarifies when plugins need to declare data, export user information, or implement specific privacy providers based on their interaction with Moodle subsystems.

documents.title: Utilities | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: While implementing the privacy API into your plugin, there are CLI scripts that can help you to test things on the fly.
documents.summary: This document provides CLI scripts designed to help developers test and verify Privacy API implementations in Moodle plugins, including compliance checking and user data export.

documents.title: Questions API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The question subsystem in Moodle manages the creation, editing and management of interactive questions, and then enables those questions to be presented to users so they can be attempted. It is useful to consider these as separate subcomponents.
documents.summary: This document explains the architecture of the Moodle question subsystem, detailing how the question engine and question bank manage interactive questions through various plugin types and core classes.

documents.title: Roles API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Roles API is an extension of the Access API and defines a set of actions
documents.summary: This document provides a technical overview of the Moodle Roles API, detailing the relationship between roles, capabilities, permissions, and context levels. It explains how to manage user access, handle capability conflicts, and implement security hardening using risk bitmasks.

documents.title: Routing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle includes a powerful routing system based upon the Slim Framework, and FastRoute.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and configure the Moodle routing system using PHP attributes and the Slim framework for RESTful web services.

documents.title: Parameters | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Routing subsystem supports three types of parameter to a request:
documents.summary: This document explains how to define, validate, and retrieve path, query, and header parameters within the routing subsystem.

documents.title: Responses | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: When creating a Route you will need to return some data. This can be achieved in a number of ways, depending on the purpose of the route and data type.
documents.summary: This document explains the required return types for routes in Moodle 4.5, focusing on the payload_response class for structured data and PSR-7 response interfaces.

documents.title: Unit Testing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: One of the benefits of using routes is how easy they are to unit test. It is also possible to test parameters for validation, which is especially useful for mapped parameters.
documents.summary: This document explains how to unit test Moodle routes using the route_testcase class and its helper methods. It provides instructions on setting up a simplified router, mocking specific routes, and simulating requests to verify route behavior and parameter validation.

documents.title: SMS API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The SMS API allows developers to implement SMS-related features into their plugins.
documents.summary: This document explains how to utilize the SMS API and the core SMS manager class to send, retrieve, and monitor SMS messages within a plugin environment.

documents.title: Tag API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Tag API allows you to assign labels to information in Moodle. This makes finding this information easier and also facilitates the grouping of similar information. The Tag API allows you to create, modify, delete and search tags in the Moodle system. The main tag related functions can be found in the tag/classes/tag.php file. For a thorough overview of all of the functions available for working with Tags please see methods in coretagtag, coretagcollection and coretagarea classes, however, the following examples should give you a general understanding of how to get started with tags.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and use the Moodle Tag API to assign, manage, and display labels for various content types within the system.

documents.title: Task API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Moodle Tasks API is a comprehensive API to support the scheduling and running of tasks. Tasks are individual activities which are to be performed, and come in two primary forms:
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the Moodle Tasks API for scheduling and managing background processes through scheduled and adhoc tasks. It details implementation best practices, error handling, security, and administrative tools for task management.

documents.title: Adhoc tasks | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Adhoc tasks are typically used when you need to queue something to run in the background either immediately, where they would be executed as soon as possible, or as a one-off task at some future point in time.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and manage adhoc tasks for background processing, covering class creation, custom data handling, and execution scheduling.

documents.title: Scheduled tasks | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Scheduled tasks are tasks that will run on a regular schedule. A default schedule can be set, but administrators have the ability to change the default schedule if required.
documents.summary: This document provides a configuration template for defining scheduled tasks within a Moodle plugin, specifying execution times and class associations.

documents.title: Time API | Moodle Developer Resources

documents.title: Git for developers | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A reasonable knowledge of the Git basics is a good idea before you start to use it for development. If you are new to Git, you are encouraged to go to the See also section on this page for some more general reading.

documents.title: Developer guides | Moodle Developer Resources

documents.title: JavaScript | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle makes heavy use of JavaScript to improve the experience for its users.
documents.summary: This document introduces the standards and best practices for developing JavaScript within Moodle, focusing on ES2015+ module structure, naming conventions, and event handling.

documents.title: AJAX | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The preferred way to write new ajax interactions in Moodle is to use the JavaScript module core/ajax which directly calls web service functions built using the Moodle Web Service API.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement AJAX interactions in Moodle using the core/ajax JavaScript module to communicate with the Web Service API.

documents.title: Combobox searching | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A combobox search component has been added to the core Moodle system. This component provides an additional layer of search functionality, allowing users to easily navigate and filter search results. The combobox search component is designed to be reusable and can be integrated into various areas of the Moodle platform.
documents.summary: This document explains how to integrate and customize the Moodle core combobox search component to create consistent search interfaces. It provides implementation steps for PHP and JavaScript along with a reference of available helper methods for extending the base class.

documents.title: Example usages | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Core Search Dropdown Migration
documents.summary: This document explains the migration of Moodle grade report modules to a new core search dropdown component and provides implementation steps for developers.

documents.title: jQuery | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A description of how and when to use jQuery in Moodle
documents.summary: This document outlines Moodle's policy and technical methods for incorporating jQuery and jQuery UI, emphasizing that native ES6 modules are preferred for modern development.

documents.title: Modal Dialogues | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The use of modal modules provides a simplified developer experience for creating modal dialogues within Moodle.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and customize accessible modal dialogues in Moodle using the core modal module, covering basic creation, standard types, and legacy support for older versions.

documents.title: Modules | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A JavaScript module is a package of code that can be reliably used and shared with other code in a reusable format.
documents.summary: This document explains how to create and use JavaScript modules in Moodle, detailing the transition from AMD to ESM format and the required development toolchain.

documents.title: Creating a reactive UI | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Third-party plugin developers are free to use any framework they want to implement reactive interfaces like React, Angular or Vue. However, for now Moodle does not provide any of them and all core developments are framework independent.
documents.summary: This document explains the architecture and implementation of Moodle's custom reactive library for building UI components that synchronize with a central state.

documents.title: YUI | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: As of Moodle 2.9 we are transitioning away from YUI to AMD modules. This transition will take a long time, but it is important because the YUI team have stopped all new development on the YUI library. See JavaScript Modules for more information.
documents.summary: This document outlines the integration of the Yahoo! User Interface (YUI) framework within Moodle, explaining its modular architecture, development tools like Grunt and JSHint, and specific configuration settings for JavaScript development.

documents.title: YUI Modules | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: As of Moodle 2.9 we are transitioning away from YUI to AMD modules. This transition will take a long time, but it is important because the YUI team have stopped all new development on the YUI library. See JavaScript Modules for more information.
documents.summary: This document provides a guide on creating and implementing YUI modules within Moodle, covering naming conventions, file structure, and integration with PHP. It explains the benefits of using YUI for dependency management and code sandboxing in plugin development.

documents.title: YUI Namespacing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: As of Moodle 2.9 we are transitioning away from YUI to AMD modules. This transition will take a long time, but it is important because the YUI team have stopped all new development on the YUI library. See JavaScript Modules for more information.
documents.summary: This document outlines the rationale and standardized naming convention for Moodle-specific YUI modules to ensure consistent sandboxing and avoid plugin conflicts.

documents.title: Profiling PHP | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: PHP has two types of profiler:
documents.summary: This document explains how to set up and use XHProf and XDebug profilers to analyze PHP performance within a Moodle environment. It provides instructions on extension installation, Moodle-specific configuration, and methods for capturing and interpreting profiling data.

documents.title: Templates | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A guide to the features and use of Mustache templating in Moodle.
documents.summary: This document explains how Moodle utilizes the Mustache template system for rendering HTML output, covering core syntax features and Moodle-specific extensions like helpers and blocks.

documents.title: Plugin Upgrades | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Upgrade API is a core API which allows your plugin to manage features of its own installation, and upgrade. Every plugin includes a version which allows the Upgrade API to apply only the required changes.
documents.summary: This document explains how Moodle plugins manage their installation and upgrade processes using the Upgrade API, specifically through key files like version.php, install.xml, and upgrade.php. It details the workflow for database schema changes and the specific coding restrictions applied during the upgrade sequence.

documents.title: Common files | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes the common files which may be present in any Moodle subsystem or plugin type. Some of these files are mandatory and must exist within a component, whilst others are optional.
documents.summary: This document outlines the standard file structure for Moodle plugins and subsystems, detailing the purpose and requirements of mandatory and optional files like version.php and install.xml.

documents.title: db/tasks.php | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A description of the plugin scheduled task configuration file
documents.summary: This document explains how to define and configure scheduled tasks for plugins, detailing the structure of the tasks.php file and the available properties for controlling timing and execution behavior.

documents.title: tag.php | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A description of the library tag.php file, describing what plugins have tags where their callbacks are located.
documents.summary: This document defines the structure and attributes for declaring tag areas in Moodle, explaining how to register database tables as taggable entities via the db/tag.php configuration file.

documents.title: version.php | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A description of the plugin version.php file, describing the various features
documents.summary: This document outlines the purpose and specific properties of the version.php file required for Moodle plugin installation, upgrades, and compatibility checks.

documents.description: Moodle provides a series of Core APIs which can be used by any part of Moodle.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the key platforms and resources within the Moodle ecosystem, including its primary products, resource-sharing network, and professional development academy.

documents.summary: This document provides technical instructions for developers to implement activity completion features in Moodle activities, covering view-based, grade-based, and custom completion criteria.

documents.summary: This document explains how to programmatically manage calendar events in Moodle using the Calendar API, covering creation, modification, deletion, and dashboard integration.

documents.title: Conditional activities API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Conditional Activities API allowsyou to specify whether to hide, or show, an activity when a series of conditions associated with it are met.
documents.summary: This document explains the Conditional Activities API, detailing how to manage activity availability through the condition_info class by fetching, updating, or deleting restricted access conditions.

documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and interact with the Custom Fields API to add configurable metadata fields to various components and plugins. It covers handler implementation, form integration, data retrieval, and privacy considerations for developers.

documents.title: Deprecation API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: When deprecating a code feature, it is often desirable to include a reasonable amount of information, and to provide a consistent deprecation message.
documents.summary: This document demonstrates how to use the core deprecation attribute in PHP to mark functions, classes, methods, and enum cases as deprecated. It highlights how to provide metadata such as replacement suggestions, versioning, and reasoning for the deprecation.

documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and manage PSR-11 compatible Dependency Injection in Moodle, covering dependency fetching, configuration via hooks, and mocking for unit tests.

documents.title: Data manipulation API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes the functions available to access data in the Moodle database. You should exclusively use these functions in order to retrieve or modify database content because these functions provide a high level of abstraction and guarantee that your database manipulation will work against different RDBMSes.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Data Manipulation API, detailing how developers use the global $DB object to perform database operations securely across different RDBMS systems. It covers fundamental concepts such as table prefixes and SQL placeholders while providing a reference for methods used to retrieve records.

documents.description: In this page you'll access to the available functions under Moodle to be able to handle DB structures (tables, fields, indexes...).
documents.summary: This document outlines the Data Definition Language (DDL) functions in Moodle used to manage database structures such as tables, fields, and indexes during installation and upgrade processes.

documents.title: Transactions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle allows data manipulation to take place within a database transaction, known as a Delegated transaction. This allows you to perform CRUD operations, and roll them back if a failure takes place.
documents.summary: This document explains the implementation and usage of delegated database transactions in Moodle for managing CRUD operations and ensuring data integrity. It details the API methods for starting, committing, and rolling back transactions, as well as rules for handling nested transactions and exceptions.

documents.title: Advanced grading API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Advanced grading was introduced in Moodle 2.2 for grading of assignments. It is intended to be used for grading of other types of activities in the later versions.
documents.summary: This document defines the architectural components of Moodle's advanced grading system and provides developer instructions for implementing it in activity modules.

documents.title: Hooks API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes the Hooks API which is a replacement for some of the lib.php based one-to-many
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Hooks API, a PSR-14 compliant system that replaces legacy plugin callbacks to allow for easier customization of core and plugin functionality.

documents.title: HTML Writer API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle has a class called HTML writer which allows you to output basic HTML tags. This is typically used within renderer functions, for example question/type/pluginname/renderer.php.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle html_writer class to programmatically generate HTML tags and attributes within PHP renderer functions.

documents.title: Lock API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Locking is required whenever you need to prevent two, or more, processes accessing the same resource at the same time. The prime candidate for locking in Moodle is cron. Locking allows multiple cron processes to work on different parts of cron at the same time with no risk that they will conflict (work on the same job at the same time).
documents.summary: This document explains the purpose and implementation of the Moodle Locking API to prevent concurrent access to shared resources across processes or cluster nodes. It provides guidance on usage, performance considerations, and instructions for configuring or extending lock factories.

documents.title: Message API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: What is this document?
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle Messaging API to programmatically send notifications and messages to users from within Moodle components and plugins.

documents.title: Navigation API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Navigation API allows for the manipulation of the navigation system used in Moodle.
documents.summary: Provides a technical overview of the Moodle Navigation API, explaining the underlying data structures, their relationship with the $PAGE object, and methods for programmatically extending navigation and settings menus.

documents.title: Preference API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Preference API is used for the storage and retrieval of user preferences. These preferences are stored in the database for users with an account, however for guests or users who are not currently logged in the preferences are stored in the Session.
documents.summary: This document explains the Preference API used for storing and retrieving user-specific settings in the database or session, detailing primary functions for managing these preferences.

documents.title: Report builder API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Overview
documents.summary: This document explains the Report Builder API, detailing how to define and implement standardized report columns, filters, and reusable entities for system and custom reporting.

documents.description: When setting up a datasource it is possible to define the default condition values for it using the getdefaultcondition_values() method.
documents.summary: This document explains how to configure default filter values for report builder datasources by implementing the get_default_condition_values method with specific key-naming conventions.
