documents.description: This is a collection of miscellaneous APIs that can help with doing things with lists of users.
documents.summary: This document outlines Moodle APIs for managing user data, including methods for displaying profile information, validating and cleaning user fields, and implementing user selection interfaces.

documents.title: API Guides | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle has a number of core APIs that provide tools for Moodle scripts.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Moodle's core and subsystem APIs, categorizing essential tools and libraries available for plugin development.

documents.title: Plugin types | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle is a powerful, and very extensible, Learning Management System. One of its core tenets is its extensibility, and this is primarily achieved through the development of plugins.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Moodle's plugin architecture, detailing mandatory naming conventions and offering a comprehensive reference of available plugin types and their directory structures.

documents.title: Antivirus plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Integrate your preferred Antivirus tool to with Moodle to automatically check new file uploads.
documents.summary: This document explains how to develop antivirus plugins for Moodle, detailing the required file structure, mandatory files, and the implementation of the scanner class for file scanning.

documents.summary: This document provides a brief overview and directory of the various platforms and services within the Moodle ecosystem, including its core products, resource sharing network, and training academy.

documents.title: Assign feedback plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Assign feedback plugins allow you to define different ways that a teacher can provide feedback to their students.
documents.summary: This document provides a technical guide on creating Moodle assignment feedback plugins, detailing the mandatory file structure, naming conventions, and core class methods required for implementation.

documents.title: Assign submission plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Assign submission plugins allow you to define different ways for a student to submit their work
documents.summary: This document provides a technical guide on developing Moodle assignment submission plugins, detailing file structure requirements, database naming conventions, and core implementation methods.

documents.title: Atto | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Atto is a JavaScript text editor built specifically for Moodle. It is the default text editor in Moodle from 2.7 onwards, and is implemented as a standard Moodle text editor plugin. Most of the code is written in JavaScript using YUI modules.
documents.summary: This document provides a boilerplate example for creating a custom button plugin within the Moodle Atto text editor using the YUI framework. It illustrates how to initialize the button, handle user interactions through callbacks, and define plugin-specific attributes.

documents.title: Availability conditions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Availability conditions allow teachers to restrict an activity or section so that only certain users can access it. These are accessed using the Availability API.
documents.summary: This document provides technical instructions for developing Moodle availability condition plugins, detailing the required file structure and PHP class implementations for managing access restrictions.

documents.title: Block plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Block plugins allow you to show supplemental information, and features, within different parts of Moodle.
documents.summary: This guide outlines the mandatory file structure and essential class definitions required to develop block plugins in Moodle, covering components like access control, language strings, and version metadata.

documents.title: Communication plugin | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Communication plugin allows you to create a communication provider plugin, which can be added as a part of course or any other instances.
documents.summary: This document explains how to develop communication provider plugins for Moodle, detailing the necessary file structure and the implementation of specific PHP interfaces for room and user management.

documents.title: Custom fields | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Custom fields allow you to create field types to be used for custom fields. Instances of these field types can be added to the respective areas that implement Custom fields API. Currently in Moodle core only courses implement this API, however custom fields are also used in addon plugins for other areas. For example, if you want to display radio buttons on the course edit page, then you can add an instance of a radio custom field plugin to the Course custom fields configuration.
documents.summary: This PHP class implements the field controller for a Moodle custom field plugin, defining its configuration form and specific settings using the Custom Fields API.

documents.title: Enrolment plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle provides a number of ways of managing course enrolment, called enrolment plugins. Each course can decide its enabled enrolment plugins instances and any enrolment plugin can define a workflow the user must follow in order to enrol in the course.
documents.summary: This document outlines the architecture and implementation requirements for Moodle enrolment plugins, detailing the necessary file structure, base classes, and database interaction.

documents.title: File Converters | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: File converters are an important tool to support other plugins with file conversion supported between a wide range of file formats. File converters are accessed using the File conversion API and are typically consumed by other plugins rather than by the user directly.
documents.summary: This document explains how to develop file converter plugins in Moodle, detailing the required file structure and the implementation of the core converter interface.

documents.title: Filter plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Filters are a way to automatically transform content before it is output. Filters may be used to:
documents.summary: This document explains how to develop and structure filter plugins in Moodle to automatically transform content before it is displayed. It covers mandatory file structures, the main filter class implementation, and best practices for ensuring filter performance.

documents.title: Course format | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Course formats are plugins that determine the layout of course resources.
documents.summary: This document explains the purpose, file structure, and implementation of course format plugins in Moodle, which control the layout and navigation of course content.

documents.title: Migrating 3.11 formats | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The new course editor introduced in Moodle 4.0 reimplements most of the previous webservices, AMD modules, and internal logic of the course rendering. However, all formats since 3.11 will use the previous libraries by default until its final deprecation in Moodle 4.3. This document collects the main adaptations any 3.11 course format will require to continue working when this happens.
documents.summary: This document outlines the architectural changes and mandatory updates required to adapt Moodle course format plugins for compatibility with the Moodle 4.0 reactive course editor.

documents.title: Local plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The recommended way to add new functionality to Moodle is to create a new standard plugin (for example, activity, block, authentication, enrol). The local plugin-type is mostly suitable for things that do not fit into these standard plugin types.
documents.summary: This document demonstrates how to extend the Moodle course administration navigation menu by adding a custom node through a local plugin hook.

documents.title: Logstore plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle supports the ability to define a custom log storage system using the logstore plugin type. This hasn't been documented yet - perhaps you are able to help us.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the various platforms and services within the Moodle ecosystem, including core products, a social network for educational resources, and professional development programs.

documents.title: Machine learning backends | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Machine learning backends process the datasets generated from the indicators and targets calculated by the Analytics API. They are used for machine learning training, prediction and models evaluation.
documents.summary: This document outlines the architecture and implementation requirements for machine learning backends within the Moodle analytics subsystem, detailing how they process datasets for training, prediction, and evaluation.

documents.title: Activity modules | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Activity modules are a fundamental course feature and are usually the primary delivery method for learning content in Moodle.
documents.summary: This document provides a template and explanation for creating the activity module configuration form in Moodle using the moodleform_mod class.

documents.title: Activity chooser | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This documentation is from the project kick-off and has not been updated since the project completed.
documents.summary: This document outlines the design improvements and technical requirements for the Moodle activity chooser update, focusing on enhancing the course creation user experience and providing new API callbacks for plugin developers.

documents.title: Module visibility and display | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Summary
documents.summary: This document explains the API for customizing how modules are displayed on the course main page, including methods for managing links, icons, and dynamic HTML content. It covers the implementation of specific functions and classes such as cached_cm_info and get_fast_modinfo to handle static and user-specific module information.

documents.description: The mod_book activity can be extended using the tool sub-plugin type. This hasn't been documented yet - perhaps you are able to help us.
documents.summary: This document provides a brief overview and links to the core platforms and services within the Moodle ecosystem, including its LMS products, resource-sharing network, and training academy.

documents.description: The mod_data activity can be extended using two sub-plugin types, namely:
documents.summary: This document provides a directory of the core websites and services within the Moodle ecosystem, highlighting its main product offerings, social resource network, and educational academy.

documents.title: Database fields | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Database activity included with Moodle includes support for several predefined field types, including text, date, and URL. It is also possible to create new field types. For example, you might like to create:
documents.summary: This guide explains how to create custom field types for the Moodle Database activity module by implementing specific sub-plugins. It covers mandatory file structures, the field class implementation, and the configuration forms required for new field behaviors.

documents.title: Database presets | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The database preset subplugin type is no longer recommended.
documents.summary: An overview of the various platforms and services offered within the Moodle ecosystem, including learning management systems, resource sharing networks, and professional development courses.

documents.title: Forum activity sub-plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The mod_forum activity can be extended using the forumreport sub-plugin type. This hasn't been documented yet - perhaps you are able to help us.
documents.summary: This document provides a brief overview and links to the primary platforms within the Moodle ecosystem, including its main product site, resource sharing network, and training academy.

documents.title: Question bank plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Question bank plugins allow you to extend the functionality of the Moodle Question bank.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Moodle question bank plugins, detailing the various ways they can extend system functionality and identifying the primary entry point for implementation.

documents.title: Question bank filters | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Question bank plugins allow you to define new filters for the question bank view and random question sets.
documents.summary: This document explains how to create and implement custom filter conditions for question bank plugins, covering both the PHP backend and JavaScript frontend components.

documents.title: Question type plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Question type plugins implement the different types of question that the core Question subsystem can handle.
documents.summary: This document provides a high-level overview of the various platforms and services within the Moodle ecosystem, including its LMS products, resource sharing network, and educational academy.

documents.title: Defaults for new questions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A way for question types to remember a user's preferred settings for creating questions of a given type.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement persistent user defaults for question type settings to ensure that a teacher's preferred configurations are automatically applied when creating new questions. It covers modifications to form classes, question-type classes, privacy provider compliance, and testing requirements.

documents.title: Repository plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Repository plugin allow Moodle to bring contents into Moodle from external repositories.
documents.summary: This document outlines the development process for Moodle repository plugins, detailng the required file structure, metadata requirements, and core class implementations.

documents.title: Theme plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A Moodle theme allows users to customize the appearance and functionality of their Moodle site, from overall design to specific activities. Users can create their own themes or modify existing ones, leveraging CSS and JavaScript for customization. The theme architecture ensures smooth fallbacks for minimal changes, fostering flexibility and ease of use.
documents.summary: This document defines the configuration settings for the Moodle Boost theme, specifying layout templates, SCSS processing, and core user interface behaviors.

documents.title: Fonts | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: CSS3 standard introduced the possibility to specify custom fonts, see CSS web fonts tutorial.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and manage custom web fonts in Moodle, covering file organization, supported formats, and CSS placeholder syntax for plugins and themes.

documents.title: Images and icons in themes | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: One of the theme features is the ability to override any of the standard images within Moodle when your theme is in use. At this point, let's explore how to utilize your own images within your theme and how to override the images being used by Moodle.
documents.summary: This document explains how to manage, implement, and override images within Moodle themes using specific directory structures, templates, and CSS.

documents.title: Layout | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: All themes are required to define the layouts they wish to be responsible for as well as create; however, many layout files are required by those layouts. If the theme is overriding another theme then it is a case of deciding which layouts this new theme should override. If the theme is a completely fresh start then you will need to define a layout for each of the different possibilities.
documents.summary: This document explains how to define, configure, and implement theme layouts in Moodle using the config.php file and mustache templates.

documents.title: Styles | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Let's begin by exploring the various locations within Moodle from which CSS can be included:
documents.summary: This document explains how CSS and SCSS are managed, organized, and included within Moodle themes and plugins. It provides guidance on writing effective CSS rules using Moodle's specific body classes and IDs to ensure style precedence and avoid collisions.

documents.title: TinyMCE Editor Plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle includes the TinyMCE text editor as standard from Moodle 4.1, and it can be installed from the plugins database for Moodle versions 3.11, and 4.0.
documents.summary: This document explains how to develop and structure subplugins for the TinyMCE text editor in Moodle, covering file organization, skeleton generation, and key JavaScript integration files.

documents.title: Testing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Testing is an important part of development and we strongly encourage you to write appropriate tests for your plugins.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for writing Behat tests for Moodle's TinyMCE editor and plugins, including required tags and available step definitions for interacting with the editor interface.

documents.title: Access API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Access API gives you functions so you can determine what the current user is allowed to do. It also allows plugins to extend Moodle with new capabilities.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Access API, which facilitates role-based access control through a hierarchical context tree and capability definitions. It provides instructions on defining capabilities in plugins, managing deprecations, and using core functions to verify user permissions.

documents.title: Admin settings | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle's configuration is stored in a mixture of the config, config_plugins, and a few other tables. These settings are edited through the administration screens, which can be accessed by going to the .../admin/index.php URL on your moodle site, or using the Administration block that appears to administrators of the Moodle front page. This page explains how the code for displaying and editing of these settings works.
documents.summary: This document explains the technical architecture of Moodle's administration settings tree and provides instructions for developers on how to define and register plugin-specific configuration settings.

documents.title: Analytics API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Analytics API allows managers to use predictions to detect trends and predict student behaviour
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Analytics API, focusing on how prediction models are defined through indicators and targets to generate actionable insights. It outlines the core components, data flow, and machine learning concepts necessary for developing and training predictive systems in Moodle.

documents.title: Availability API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The availability API controls access to activities and sections. For example, a teacher could restrict access so that an activity cannot be accessed until a certain date, or so that a section cannot be accessed unless users have a certain grade in a quiz.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle Availability API to manage and restrict user access to course activities and sections based on specific criteria. It covers checking visibility permissions for individuals, filtering user lists, and programmatically configuring availability restrictions.

documents.title: Backup API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Backup API provides a way to include your plugin's in the course backup. See Restore API for the part that takes care of restoring data.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement the Moodle Backup API to include custom plugin data in course backups using specialized task and step classes.

documents.title: Restore API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Restore API provides a way to restore your plugin's data from a backup file created in Moodle 2.0 or later. For the information on how backup files are created, see Backup API. For the information on how to support restoring data from backup files created in Moodle 1.x, see Backup conversion API.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle Restore API to recover plugin data from backup files, detailing the required file structures, restore plans, tasks, and steps.

documents.title: Check API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A Check is a runtime test to make sure that something is working well. You can think of Checks as similar and complimentary to the PHPUnit and Acceptance testing but the next layer around them, and performed at run time rather than development, or build time.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Check API, a framework for performing runtime tests on system configuration, security, and performance, and provides guidance on implementing custom checks.

documents.title: Communication API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Communication API provides access to the messaging system and other communication providers (such as Matrix).
documents.summary: This document explains the Communication API, which enables asynchronous management of rooms and members across different messaging providers through ad-hoc tasks and hooks.

documents.title: Editor API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The editor API lets you control Moodle text editors. It can be found in lib/editorlib.php.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle Editor API to programmatically enable and configure text editors on HTML text area elements.

documents.title: Enrolment API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The enrolment API gives access to the enrolment methods and also to enrolment plugins instances.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle enrolment API, detailing the technical distinction between user enrolments and role assignments while providing functional methods for managing course participation. It describes how to programmatically check enrolment status, retrieve participant lists, and interact with enrolment plugins to modify user records.

documents.title: External Services | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle has a full-featured Web Service framework, allowing you to use and create web services for use in external systems.
documents.summary: This document introduces the Moodle Web Service framework and External API, providing an overview of its internal uses and a directory of resources for developing, securing, and implementing web services.

documents.title: Service creation | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle comes with two built-in services that your functions can be attached to.
documents.summary: This document defines the structure for configuring external services in Moodle, specifying settings for functions, capabilities, and file handling permissions.

documents.title: Function Declarations | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Before they can be used, all functions must be declared to Moodle, and their inputs and outputs must be defined.
documents.summary: This document outlines the structure for defining and registering web service functions within a Moodle plugin configuration file.

documents.title: File handling | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle provides two ways to fetch and upload files:
documents.summary: This document explains the available methods for uploading and fetching files in Moodle using either specific web service functions or dedicated HTTP endpoints.

documents.title: Function Definitions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: An External function definition is the class, and collection of functions, used to define:
documents.summary: This document defines a Moodle external API class for programmatically creating groups within courses, specifying the required parameters, security checks, and return structures.

documents.title: Security | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Before operating on any data in an external function, you must ensure that the user:
documents.summary: This document outlines the essential security and validation requirements for implementing Moodle external functions, focusing on parameter verification, context validation, and capability checks.

documents.title: Unit Testing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Unit tests are the best way of checking the behaviour of your external services and can help you to:
documents.summary: This document provides unit tests for a Moodle external function, demonstrating how to verify capability checks and API execution within a custom module.

documents.title: Writing a new service | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This documentation covers the creation of a new external service for use in a web service of a fictional local plugin, local_groupmanager.
documents.summary: This document explains how to create and implement a new external web service function within a Moodle plugin, covering naming conventions, service declaration, and technical implementation details.

documents.title: Favourites API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Overview
documents.summary: This document outlines the usage of the Favourites API in Moodle for marking and managing items as user favourites across various components and contexts. It describes the core service layer methods for performing CRUD operations and integrating favourite data into external database queries.

documents.title: File API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The File API is used to control, manage, and serve all files uploaded and stored within Moodle. This page covers the core File API, which is responsible for storage, retrieval, and serving of files stored in Moodle.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Moodle's core File API, explaining how to manage file storage through defined file areas and how to serve files to users using URL generation and component callbacks.

documents.title: File Browser API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The File Browser API is a supplemental API which can be used to fetch information relating to Files stored in the Moodle File API.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the File Browser API to retrieve metadata and hierarchical information for files stored within the Moodle File API.

documents.title: File Converters | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Users are able to submit a wide range of files, and it is a common requirement to convert these to alternative formats.
documents.summary: This document explains how to utilize Moodle's File Converter API to transform files between formats, covering conversion initiation, status tracking, and file retrieval.

documents.title: File API internals | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The goals of the File API are to:
documents.summary: This document provides a conceptual and technical overview of Moodle's File API, explaining its architecture, storage mechanisms, and the core components used to manage and serve site content.

documents.title: Forms API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Form are created using the Form API. The Form API supports most standard HTML elements, including checkboxes, radio buttons, text boxes, and so on, adding additional accessibility and security features to them.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle Form API to create, process, and render secure, accessible forms by extending the moodleform class.

documents.title: Advanced elements | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Form elements can be marked as 'advanced'. This has the effect that they are hidden initially.
documents.summary: This document explains how to manage advanced form elements in Moodle using the setAdvanced method to hide specific fields or entire sections initially. It details how to toggle advanced status and the importance of using unique header names to prevent unintended layout behavior.

documents.title: Checkbox controller | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The checkbox controller allows developers to group checkboxes together and add a link or button to check, or uncheck, all of the checkboxes at once.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement grouped checkboxes and checkbox controllers in a form to allow users to toggle multiple selections at once.

documents.title: No submit button | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The moodleform 'nosubmitbutton_pressed()' method allows you to detect if a button on your form has been pressed that is a submit button but that has been defined as a button that doesn't result in a processing of all the form data but will result in some form 'sub action' and then having the form redisplayed. This is useful for example to have an 'Add' button to add some option to a select box in the form etc. You define a button as a no submit button as in the example below (in definition()). This example adds a text box and a submit button in a group.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the no_submit_button_pressed() method in Moodle forms to handle sub-actions that redisplay the form instead of completing a final submission.

documents.title: Repeat elements | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Form API includes the ability to repeat a group of form elements. This is useful where you need to have an unknown quantity of item data, for example possible answers in a quiz question.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the repeat_elements method in the Form API to create dynamic, repeating groups of form fields that allow for an unknown number of user inputs.

documents.title: Choice Dropdown | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The choicedropdown form field creates a dropdown list with multiple options. It is different from a standard select dropdown in that each option can have extra icons and descriptions. This field is often used in forms to facilitate the selection of a non-trivial option that demands additional information.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement the choicedropdown form field and the choicelist data definition to create rich dropdown menus with icons and descriptions.

documents.title: Form Usage | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle's Form API is an extension of the Pear HTMLQuickForm API, which is no longer supported. Some documentation for the upstream library is available in the PEAR package page, including a short tutorial. A longer tutorial is also available, courtesy of the Internet Archive.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Form API, detailing how to define form classes, process submitted data, and implement standard forms within activity modules.

documents.title: Files in Forms | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Files and their metadata are stored within the File API. Each file within the API is associated with:
documents.summary: This document explains how to integrate file upload and management capabilities into Moodle forms using the filepicker, filemanager, and editor elements. It provides a workflow for handling draft file areas and moving files to permanent storage within the Moodle File API.

documents.title: Groups API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle Groups are a way of expressing collections of users within a course. They may be defined by the teacher in the course participants page, or created automatically during a bulk user upload (for example, from a text file).
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Groups system, covering group modes, visibility settings, and the Groups API for developers. It describes how to manage collections of users within courses and activities and implement group support in activity modules.

documents.title: Cache API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This document provides an in-depth overview of the Cache API, also known as MUC (Moodle Universal Cache), a fundamental caching system within Moodle.
documents.summary: This document explains the implementation and configuration of the Moodle Universal Cache (MUC) API for plugin developers. It details how to create cache definitions, manage data using the cache object, and configure advanced requirements for different cache modes.

documents.title: Output API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Output API is responsible for visual aspects of Moodle content. This page explains how renderers, renderables, themes and templates all work together.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Output API and how renderers, renderables, and templates interact to generate visual content. It describes the lifecycle of page rendering, including the role of the global $PAGE variable and the implementation of renderable interfaces.

documents.title: Inplace editable | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The inplace_editable element is a mini-API which allows developers to easily support editing of a value on any page. The interface is used in places such as the course section and activity name editing.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement the inplace_editable mini-API in Moodle plugins to allow users to edit values directly on a page. It covers callback definitions, renderer integration, and configuring different UI types like toggles and dropdowns.

documents.title: Plagiarism API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Overview
documents.summary: This document provides a directory of Moodle's core platforms and services, including its main product site, resource-sharing social network, and professional training academy.

documents.title: Privacy API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is an EU directive that provides users with more control over their data and how it is processed. This regulation came into effect on 25th of May 2018 and covers any citizen or permanent resident of the European Union. The directive is respected by a number of other countries outside of the European Union.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions for Moodle plugin developers on implementing the Privacy API to ensure compliance with GDPR requirements. It describes the architecture of the core_privacy subsystem and the necessary PHP interfaces for managing user data access and deletion.

documents.title: FAQs | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: My plugin sends notifications or messages to the user - do I need to return this user data?
documents.summary: This document provides guidance for Moodle developers on how to handle user data and privacy requirements within various plugin types to ensure compliance with the Privacy API.

documents.title: Utilities | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: While implementing the privacy API into your plugin, there are CLI scripts that can help you to test things on the fly.
documents.summary: This document provides a set of PHP command-line scripts designed to help developers test and verify the implementation of the Moodle Privacy API within their plugins.

documents.title: Questions API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The question subsystem in Moodle manages the creation, editing and management of interactive questions, and then enables those questions to be presented to users so they can be attempted. It is useful to consider these as separate subcomponents.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the Moodle question subsystem architecture, covering the interaction between the question engine, question bank, and various plugin types.

documents.title: Roles API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Roles API is an extension of the Access API and defines a set of actions
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Roles API architecture, detailing how permissions, capabilities, and roles are defined and applied across various hierarchical context levels. It also covers permission conflict resolution, security risk bitmasks, and the programming interface for managing role archetypes.

documents.title: Tag API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Tag API allows you to assign labels to information in Moodle. This makes finding this information easier and also facilitates the grouping of similar information. The Tag API allows you to create, modify, delete and search tags in the Moodle system. The main tag related functions can be found in the tag/classes/tag.php file. For a thorough overview of all of the functions available for working with Tags please see methods in coretagtag, coretagcollection and coretagarea classes, however, the following examples should give you a general understanding of how to get started with tags.
documents.summary: This document provides a technical overview of the Moodle Tag API, explaining how to define tag areas, integrate tagging functionality into forms, and manage tag instances within custom plugins.

documents.title: Task API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Moodle Tasks API is a comprehensive API to support the scheduling and running of tasks. Tasks are individual activities which are to be performed, and come in two primary forms:
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Tasks API for background processing, detailing the implementation and management of scheduled and adhoc tasks along with error handling and security considerations.

documents.title: Adhoc tasks | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Adhoc tasks are typically used when you need to queue something to run in the background either immediately, where they would be executed as soon as possible, or as a one-off task at some future point in time.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement and manage adhoc background tasks for one-off or delayed execution within a plugin environment. It covers task creation, custom data handling, user context settings, and advanced queuing features like duplicate detection and retry policies.

documents.title: Scheduled tasks | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Scheduled tasks are tasks that will run on a regular schedule. A default schedule can be set, but administrators have the ability to change the default schedule if required.
documents.summary: Demonstrates how to configure scheduled tasks in a Moodle plugin by defining task classes and their specific execution schedules.

documents.title: Time API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Internally Moodle always stores all times in unixtime format (number of seconds since epoch) which is independent of timezones.
documents.summary: This document explains how Moodle's Time API manages and displays date-time information across different timezones using the core_date class. It details the distinction between system and user time while providing functions for safe timestamp manipulation and formatting.

documents.title: xAPI (Experience API) | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Overview
documents.summary: This document explains the technical implementation of the Moodle xAPI integration library, detailing how it processes learning statements and state data through specific web services and PHP handler classes.

documents.summary: This document provides a brief overview of the key platforms within the Moodle ecosystem, including its main product site, resource-sharing social network, and professional development academy.

documents.description: Moodle makes heavy use of JavaScript to improve the experience for its users.

It explains how to structure and integrate JavaScript code within the Moodle ecosystem to ensure maintainability and performance.

documents.title: AJAX | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The preferred way to write new ajax interactions in Moodle is to use the JavaScript module core/ajax which directly calls web service functions built using the Moodle Web Service API.
documents.summary: This document provides instructions and best practices for implementing AJAX interactions in Moodle using the core/ajax JavaScript module and Web Service API. It covers the setup of web services for AJAX, common design patterns like the repository model, and handling chained requests or sessionless calls.

documents.title: Modules | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A JavaScript module is a package of code that can be reliably used and shared with other code in a reusable format.
documents.summary: Explains the implementation and management of JavaScript modules in Moodle, covering the transition to ES Modules, the transpilation process, and integration with PHP and templates.

documents.title: Creating a reactive UI | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Third-party plugin developers are free to use any framework they want to implement reactive interfaces like React, Angular or Vue. However, for now Moodle does not provide any of them and all core developments are framework independant.
documents.summary: This document explains Moodle's internal reactive library and the architectural patterns used to build state-driven user interface components in plugins.

documents.title: YUI | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: As of Moodle 2.9 we are transitioning away from YUI to AMD modules. This transition will take a long time, but it is important because the YUI team have stopped all new development on the YUI library. See JavaScript Modules for more information.
documents.summary: This document explains the integration of the YUI framework within Moodle, covering its modular structure, development tools, and configuration settings for JavaScript debugging.

documents.title: YUI Modules | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: As of Moodle 2.9 we are transitioning away from YUI to AMD modules. This transition will take a long time, but it is important because the YUI team have stopped all new development on the YUI library. See JavaScript Modules for more information.

documents.title: YUI Namespacing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: As of Moodle 2.9 we are transitioning away from YUI to AMD modules. This transition will take a long time, but it is important because the YUI team have stopped all new development on the YUI library. See JavaScript Modules for more information.

documents.description: The Upgrade API is a core API which allows your plugin to manage features of its own installation, and upgrade. Every plugin includes a version which allows the Upgrade API to apply only the required changes.

documents.title: Common files | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes the common files which may be present in any Moodle subsystem or plugin type. Some of these files are mandatory and must exist within a component, whilst others are optional.
documents.summary: This document describes the mandatory and optional files required for Moodle plugins and subsystems, explaining their specific roles in installation, upgrades, and localization.

documents.title: db/tasks.php | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A description of the plugin scheduled task configuration file
documents.summary: This document explains how to define and configure scheduled tasks for a plugin by implementing a specific PHP class and defining properties in a configuration file. It details the available settings for scheduling, execution blocking, and task status.

documents.title: tag.php | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A description of the library tag.php file, describing what plugins have tags where their callbacks are located.
documents.summary: This document defines the configuration schema and attributes for registering tag areas within the Moodle tagging system. It explains how to specify item types, components, and callbacks to integrate tagging functionality into core features or plugins.

documents.title: version.php | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A description of the plugin version.php file, describing the various features
documents.summary: This document explains the required structure and properties of the version.php file for Moodle plugins, which manages installation, version tracking, and compatibility requirements.

documents.title: Core APIs | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle provides a series of Core APIs which can be used by any part of Moodle.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the primary websites and resources within the Moodle ecosystem, including its products, social network for educational resources, and professional development academy.

documents.title: Activity completion API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: There are changes to the completion API introduced in Moodle 3.11 to be incorporated to this page. Please refer to Student activity completion for details.
documents.summary: This document provides technical instructions for developers on how to implement and support the completion system in Moodle activities, covering view-based, grade-based, and custom completion rules.

documents.title: Calendar API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page documents the Calendar API as it is in Moodle 3.3 and later. For the API in older versions of Moodle, see Calendar API old.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle Calendar API to programmatically create, update, and delete events, as well as how to implement action events for dashboard integration.

documents.title: Conditional activities API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Conditional Activities API allowsyou to specify whether to hide, or show, an activity when a series of conditions associated with it are met.
documents.summary: This document provides a technical overview of the Conditional Activities API, detailing how to manage activity availability through the condition_info class and its methods. it explains how to fetch, update, and delete conditions related to course module visibility based on completion, grades, and dates.

documents.title: Data manipulation API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This page describes the functions available to access data in the Moodle database. You should exclusively use these functions in order to retrieve or modify database content because these functions provide a high level of abstraction and guarantee that your database manipulation will work against different RDBMSes.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Data Manipulation API, detailing how to use the $DB global object for secure, cross-database compatible operations. It provides guidance on core concepts like SQL placeholders and table prefixes alongside a reference for various record retrieval functions.

documents.title: Database schema | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The files available here are in DBDesigner4 format. DBDesigner4 is a schema drawing program released under GPL.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the core platforms within the Moodle ecosystem, including its primary product site, resource-sharing network, and professional development academy.

documents.title: Data definition API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: In this page you'll access to the available functions under Moodle to be able to handle DB structures (tables, fields, indexes...).
documents.summary: This document provides a reference for Moodle's DDL API functions, which are used to manage database structures like tables, fields, and indexes specifically during installation and upgrade processes.

documents.title: Transactions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle allows data manipulation to take place within a database transaction, known as a Delegated transaction. This allows you to perform CRUD operations, and roll them back if a failure takes place.
documents.summary: This document explains the principles and implementation of delegated database transactions in Moodle, detailing the API for handling nested CRUD operations and error recovery.

documents.title: DML drivers | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A number of native drivers are included with Moodle, including those with support for:
documents.summary: This document outlines the native database drivers supported by Moodle and provides instructions for configuring query logging to monitor performance and errors.

documents.title: DML exceptions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The DML API uses a selection of exceptions to indicate errors.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the key platforms within the Moodle ecosystem, including its primary product site, educational resource network, and professional development academy.

documents.title: Advanced grading API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Advanced grading was introduced in Moodle 2.2 for grading of assignments. It is intended to be used for grading of other types of activities in the later versions.
documents.summary: This document outlines the architectural components of the Moodle advanced grading system and provides a technical guide for developers to integrate these methods into activity modules.

documents.title: HTML Writer API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle has a class called HTML writer which allows you to output basic HTML tags. This is typically used within renderer functions, for example question/type/pluginname/renderer.php.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle HTML writer class to programmatically generate HTML tags within renderer functions.

documents.title: Lock API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Locking is required whenever you need to prevent two, or more, processes accessing the same resource at the same time. The prime candidate for locking in Moodle is cron. Locking allows multiple cron processes to work on different parts of cron at the same time with no risk that they will conflict (work on the same job at the same time).
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Locking API, detailing how to prevent concurrent access to shared resources across processes and cluster nodes. It covers performance considerations, implementation patterns using lock factories, and configuration of different lock types.

documents.title: Navigation API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Navigation API allows for the manipulation of the navigation system used in Moodle.
documents.summary: This document explains the architecture and implementation of the Moodle Navigation API, detailing how the system manages site structure, settings, and breadcrumbs through the global page object.

documents.title: Preference API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Preference API is used for the storage and retrieval of user preferences. These preferences are stored in the database for users with an account, however for guests or users who are not currently logged in the preferences are stored in the Session.
documents.summary: This document describes the Preference API used for storing and retrieving persistent user-specific settings in the database or temporary session data for guests. It provides technical details on core functions for managing preferences and outlines best practices for handling default values.

documents.title: User-related APIs | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This is a collection of miscellaneous APIs that can help with doing things with lists of users.
documents.summary: This document outlines the miscellaneous APIs in Moodle for handling user lists, specifically focusing on user field display, validation, sanitization, and UI selection components.

documents.title: API Guides | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle has a number of core APIs that provide tools for Moodle scripts.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the core and general APIs in Moodle that developers use to build plugins and manage system functionalities like data, files, and user interfaces.

documents.title: Plugin types | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle is a powerful, and very extensible, Learning Management System. One of its core tenets is its extensibility, and this is primarily achieved through the development of plugins.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the Moodle plugin system, including mandatory naming conventions, common file structures, and a comprehensive reference list of available plugin types.

documents.title: Antivirus plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Integrate your preferred Antivirus tool to with Moodle to automatically check new file uploads.
documents.summary: This document explains how to develop antivirus plugins for Moodle to enable automatic virus scanning for uploaded files, covering file structure and mandatory implementation files.

documents.title: Assignment sub-plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The mod_assign activity can be extended using two sub-plugin types, namely:
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the key platforms and resources within the Moodle ecosystem, including its core products, educational resource sharing network, and professional development academy.

documents.title: Assign feedback plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Assign feedback plugins allow you to define different ways that a teacher can provide feedback to their students.
documents.summary: This document provides technical instructions for developing Moodle assignment feedback plugins, detailing the required file structure, naming conventions, and core class methods.

documents.title: Assign submission plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Assign submission plugins allow you to define different ways for a student to submit their work
documents.summary: This document explains the technical requirements and implementation details for creating custom assignment submission plugins, including file structure, naming conventions, and essential class methods.

documents.title: Atto | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Atto is a JavaScript text editor built specifically for Moodle. It is the default text editor in Moodle from 2.7 onwards, and is implemented as a standard Moodle text editor plugin. Most of the code is written in JavaScript using YUI modules.
documents.summary: This document provides a boilerplate implementation for creating a custom button in the Moodle Atto text editor using the YUI framework. It demonstrates how to initialize the button, define keyboard shortcuts, and manage plugin attributes.

documents.title: Availability conditions | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Availability conditions allow teachers to restrict an activity or section so that only certain users can access it. These are accessed using the Availability API.
documents.summary: This document outlines the development process for Moodle availability condition plugins, explaining the directory structure and required PHP classes for implementing custom access restrictions.

documents.title: Block plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Block plugins allow you to show supplemental information, and features, within different parts of Moodle.
documents.summary: This document explains the standard file structure and implementation requirements for creating block plugins in Moodle, including class definitions and mandatory configuration files.

documents.title: Course Custom fields | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Course custom fields allow you to create field types to be used for course custom fields. Instances of these field types can be added to a course. for example, if you want to display radio buttons on the course edit page, then you can create a radio custom course field plugin.
documents.summary: This document defines a Moodle field controller class used to create and configure custom field settings using the MoodleQuickForm API.

documents.title: Enrolment plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle provides a number of ways of managing course enrolment, called enrolment plugins. Each course can decide its enabled enrolment plugins instances and any enrolment plugin can define a workflow the user must follow in order to enrol in the course.
documents.summary: This document explains the architecture and development requirements for Moodle enrolment plugins, detailing their file structure, base classes, and core functionalities.

documents.title: File Converters | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: File converters are an important tool to support other plugins with file conversion supported between a wide range of file formats. File converters are accessed using the File conversion API and are typically consumed by other plugins rather than by the user directly.
documents.summary: This document explains the technical structure and implementation requirements for creating file converter plugins in Moodle, detailing mandatory files and the converter interface.

documents.title: Filter plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Filters are a way to automatically transform content before it is output. Filters may be used to:
documents.summary: This document provides a guide on developing filter plugins in Moodle to automatically transform text content before it is rendered. It outlines the required file structure, class implementation, and performance best practices for efficient content processing.

documents.title: Course format | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Course formats are plugins that determine the layout of course resources.
documents.summary: This document explains how to develop course format plugins in Moodle, detailing the required file structure and the implementation of key components like the format base class and rendering logic.

documents.title: Migrating 3.11 formats | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The new course editor introduced in Moodle 4.0 reimplements most of the previous webservices, AMD modules, and internal logic of the course rendering. However, all formats since 3.11 will use the previous libraries by default until its final deprecation in Moodle 4.3. This document collects the main adaptations any 3.11 course format will require to continue working when this happens.
documents.summary: Explains the architectural changes in the Moodle 4.0 course editor and provides guidance for developers to migrate course format plugins from Moodle 3.11 to the new reactive component system.

documents.title: Local plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The recommended way to add new functionality to Moodle is to create a new standard plugin (for example, activity, block, authentication, enrol). The local plugin-type is mostly suitable for things that do not fit into these standard plugin types.

documents.title: TinyMCE Editor Plugins | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle includes the TinyMCE text editor as standard from Moodle 4.1, and it can be installed from the plugins database for Moodle versions 3.11, and 4.0.

documents.title: Access API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Access API gives you functions so you can determine what the current user is allowed to do. It also allows plugins to extend Moodle with new capabilities.

documents.title: Admin settings | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle's configuration is stored in a mixture of the config, config_plugins, and a few other tables. These settings are edited through the administration screens, which can be accessed by going to the .../admin/index.php URL on your moodle site, or using the Administration block that appears to administrators of the Moodle front page. This page explains how the code for displaying and editing of these settings works.
documents.summary: Explains the architecture and implementation of the Moodle administration settings tree, providing details on how to define and register configuration options for plugins.

documents.title: Analytics API | Moodle Developer Resources

documents.title: Availability API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The availability API controls access to activities and sections. For example, a teacher could restrict access so that an activity cannot be accessed until a certain date, or so that a section cannot be accessed unless users have a certain grade in a quiz.

documents.title: Backup API | Moodle Developer Resources

documents.title: Restore API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Restore API provides a way to restore your plugin's data from a backup file created in Moodle 2.0 or later. For the information on how backup files are created, see Backup API. For the information on how to support restoring data from backup files created in Moodle 1.x, see Backup conversion API.
documents.summary: This document explains how to implement the Restore API in Moodle plugins to recover data from backup files using restore plans, tasks, and steps.

documents.title: Check API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: A Check is a runtime test to make sure that something is working well. You can think of Checks as similar and complimentary to the PHPUnit and Acceptance testing but the next layer around them, and performed at run time rather than development, or build time.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Check API, a framework for performing runtime tests to monitor system configuration, security, and performance within the Moodle environment.

documents.title: Editor API | Moodle Developer Resources

documents.title: External Services | Moodle Developer Resources

documents.title: File handling | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle provides two ways to fetch and upload files:
documents.summary: This document explains how to fetch and upload files in Moodle using web service functions and dedicated endpoints, highlighting best practices for handling large files and authentication.

documents.description: An External function definition is the class, and collection of functions, used to define:
documents.summary: This document defines a PHP class for a Moodle external API function that allows the creation of groups within a course through a structured web service interface.

documents.title: Security | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Before operating on any data in an external function, you must ensure that the user:
documents.summary: This document explains the mandatory security procedures for Moodle external functions, including parameter validation, context verification, and user capability checks.

documents.title: Unit Testing | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Unit tests are the best way of checking the behaviour of your external services and can help you to:
documents.summary: This document provides automated unit tests for evaluating the capability requirements and execution logic of Moodle external functions.

documents.title: Writing a new service | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: This documentation covers the creation of a new external service for use in a web service of a fictional local plugin, local_groupmanager.
documents.summary: This document explains how to create and define custom web services within Moodle plugins using the External functions API. It covers naming conventions, service registration in configuration files, and the implementation of parameter and return value structures in PHP.

documents.title: Favourites API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Overview
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle Favourites API to manage user-specific bookmarks for various system items. It details the identification requirements for items and provides instructions for performing CRUD operations and integrating favourites into SQL queries.

documents.title: File API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The File API is used to control, manage, and serve all files uploaded and stored within Moodle. This page covers the core File API, which is responsible for storage, retrieval, and serving of files stored in Moodle.
documents.summary: This document explains the core Moodle File API, detailing how files are organized into file areas and providing instructions on generating secure URLs and implementing callbacks to serve files.

documents.title: File Browser API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The File Browser API is a supplemental API which can be used to fetch information relating to Files stored in the Moodle File API.
documents.summary: This document describes the Moodle File Browser API, which is used to retrieve hierarchical information and metadata for files stored within the Moodle File API system.

documents.title: File Converters | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Users are able to submit a wide range of files, and it is a common requirement to convert these to alternative formats.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Moodle's file converter API, explaining how to initiate file conversions, track their status, and retrieve the resulting files.

documents.title: File API internals | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The goals of the File API are to:

It describes the core components of the API including the file system, storage metadata, and access control mechanisms for plugin integration.

documents.title: Forms API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Form are created using the Form API. The Form API supports most standard HTML elements, including checkboxes, radio buttons, text boxes, and so on, adding additional accessibility and security features to them.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle Form API to create, define, and process accessible and secure forms within the Moodle environment. It covers extending the moodleform class and managing various form elements and data validation.

documents.title: Advanced elements | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Form elements can be marked as 'advanced'. This has the effect that they are hidden initially.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the setAdvanced method in Moodle's form library to hide specific form elements or entire sections until the user chooses to show them.

documents.title: Checkbox controller | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The checkbox controller allows developers to group checkboxes together and add a link or button to check, or uncheck, all of the checkboxes at once.
documents.summary: This document demonstrates how to group checkboxes in Moodle forms and implement a checkbox controller to provide select-all functionality for those groups.

documents.title: No submit button | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The moodleform 'nosubmitbutton_pressed()' method allows you to detect if a button on your form has been pressed that is a submit button but that has been defined as a button that doesn't result in a processing of all the form data but will result in some form 'sub action' and then having the form redisplayed. This is useful for example to have an 'Add' button to add some option to a select box in the form etc. You define a button as a no submit button as in the example below (in definition()). This example adds a text box and a submit button in a group.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle moodleform method no_submit_button_pressed() to handle form actions that require redisplaying the form without processing final submission data.

documents.title: Repeat elements | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Form API includes the ability to repeat a group of form elements. This is useful where you need to have an unknown quantity of item data, for example possible answers in a quiz question.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the repeat_elements method in the Form API to create repeating groups of form elements for handling dynamic quantities of input data.

documents.title: Form Usage | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle's Form API is an extension of the Pear HTMLQuickForm API, which is no longer supported. Some documentation for the upstream library is available in the PEAR package page, including a short tutorial. A longer tutorial is also available, courtesy of the Internet Archive.
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of Moodle's Form API, explaining how to create form classes, handle data submission, and integrate forms into activity modules.

documents.title: Groups API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Moodle Groups are a way of expressing collections of users within a course. They may be defined by the teacher in the course participants page, or created automatically during a bulk user upload (for example, from a text file).
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle groups and groupings system and provides guidance on using the Groups API to implement group-aware features in activities.

documents.title: Output API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Output API is responsible for visual aspects of Moodle content. This page explains how renderers, renderables, themes and templates all work together.

documents.description: Overview
documents.summary: This document provides a directory of core platforms within the Moodle ecosystem, including product information, resource sharing networks, and professional development resources.

documents.title: Privacy API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is an EU directive that provides users with more control over their data and how it is processed. This regulation came into effect on 25th of May 2018 and covers any citizen or permanent resident of the European Union. The directive is respected by a number of other countries outside of the European Union.
documents.summary: This document outlines the API changes and implementation requirements for Moodle plugin developers to ensure GDPR compliance through the core_privacy subsystem.

documents.title: FAQs | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: My plugin sends notifications or messages to the user - do I need to return this user data?
documents.summary: Provides guidance for Moodle developers on handling user data, privacy providers, and metadata declarations across various plugin types and scenarios.

documents.title: Utilities | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: While implementing the privacy API into your plugin, there are CLI scripts that can help you to test things on the fly.
documents.summary: This document provides a collection of CLI scripts designed to help developers test and verify their Privacy API implementations within Moodle plugins.

documents.title: Roles API | Moodle Developer Resources

documents.summary: This document explains the architecture of the Moodle Roles API, defining how roles, capabilities, and permissions interact within various contexts to manage user access and system security.

documents.title: Tag API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Tag API allows you to assign labels to information in Moodle. This makes finding this information easier and also facilitates the grouping of similar information. The Tag API allows you to create, modify, delete and search tags in the Moodle system. The main tag related functions can be found in the tag/classes/tag.php file. For a thorough overview of all of the functions available for working with Tags please see methods in coretagtag, coretagcollection and coretagarea classes, however, the following examples should give you a general understanding of how to get started with tags.
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Tag API, providing developers with instructions and code examples for defining tag areas, integrating tags into forms, and managing tag instances within plugins.

documents.title: Task API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Moodle Tasks API is a comprehensive API to support the scheduling and running of tasks. Tasks are individual activities which are to be performed, and come in two primary forms:
documents.summary: This document provides an overview of the Moodle Tasks API, explaining how to implement and manage scheduled and adhoc background tasks. it covers key technical considerations including error handling, caching, security, and the transition from legacy cron systems.

documents.title: Adhoc tasks | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Adhoc tasks are typically used when you need to queue something to run in the background either immediately, where they would be executed as soon as possible, or as a one-off task at some future point in time.
documents.summary: This document explains how to create, queue, and manage adhoc background tasks for asynchronous processing, including setting custom data and execution times. It details how to extend the base task class and utilize the task manager for features like duplicate detection and rescheduling.

documents.title: Scheduled tasks | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Scheduled tasks are tasks that will run on a regular schedule. A default schedule can be set, but administrators have the ability to change the default schedule if required.
documents.summary: This document defines the configuration template for scheduling background tasks in a Moodle plugin, including timing and execution parameters.

documents.title: Time API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Internally Moodle always stores all times in unixtime format (number of seconds since epoch) which is independent of timezones.
documents.summary: This document explains how to use the Moodle Time API to manage and display date-time information based on system or user-specific timezones. It outlines the usage of the core_date class and PHP DateTime objects to handle unixtime storage and daylight saving time calculations.

You should exclusively use these functions in order to retrieve or modify database content because these functions provide a high level of abstraction and guarantee that your database manipulation will work against different RDBMSes.
documents.summary: This document describes the Moodle Data Manipulation API (DML), explaining how to use the global $DB object to interact with the database securely and across different RDBMS platforms. It covers fundamental concepts like table prefixes, SQL placeholders, and specific methods for retrieving single or multiple records.

documents.title: Lock API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Locking is required whenever you need to prevent two, or more, processes accessing the same resource at the same time. The prime candidate for locking in Moodle is cron. Locking allows multiple cron processes to work on different parts of cron at the same time with no risk that they will conflict (work on the same job at the same time).
documents.summary: This document explains the Moodle Locking API, which prevents concurrent process access to shared resources. It covers usage patterns, performance considerations, and the configuration of lock factories.

documents.title: Custom fields | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: Custom fields allow you to create field types to be used for custom fields. Instances of these field types can be added to the respective areas that implement Custom fields API. Currently in Moodle core only courses implement this API, however custom fields are also used in addon plugins for other areas. For example, if you want to display radio buttons on the course edit page, then you can add an instance of a radio custom field plugin to the Course custom fields configuration.
documents.summary: This document defines the field controller class for a Moodle custom field plugin, specifying how to configure the field's settings via a form definition.

documents.title: Choice Dropdown | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The choicedropdown form field creates a dropdown list with multiple options. It is different from a standard select dropdown in that each option can have extra icons and descriptions. This field is often used in forms to facilitate the selection of a non-trivial option that demands additional information.

documents.title: Privacy API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is an EU directive that provides users with more control over their data and how it is processed. This regulation came into effect on 25th of May 2018 and covers any citizen or permanent resident of the European Union. The directive is respected by a number of other countries outside of the European Union.
documents.summary: This document provides technical guidance for Moodle plugin developers on implementing the Privacy API to ensure software compliance with GDPR data protection requirements.

documents.title: Tag API | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: The Tag API allows you to assign labels to information in Moodle. This makes finding this information easier and also facilitates the grouping of similar information. The Tag API allows you to create, modify, delete and search tags in the Moodle system. The main tag related functions can be found in the tag/classes/tag.php file. For a thorough overview of all of the functions available for working with Tags please see methods in coretagtag, coretagcollection and coretagarea classes, however, the following examples should give you a general understanding of how to get started with tags.

documents.title: DevDocs Migration | Moodle Developer Resources
documents.description: <ProjectSummary
documents.summary: This document outlines the strategic transition of Moodle's developer documentation from a legacy MediaWiki platform to Docusaurus to improve versioning, searchability, and ease of editing. It details the selection criteria for the new system, planned features like automated checks, and the structured three-phase migration roadmap.
